title: Are intelligent people more likely to be alone? - Quora

response.answer_text: Definitely. Not only there is the thrice-goddamned communication range of 30 points, making any meaningful interaction with the normies impossible. There is an eponymous French saying (whose actual name escapes my mind) that if the IQ of two persons differ more than 20 points, after half an hour of discussion both are convinced the other guy is an idiot. But also certain personality traits which contribute the preference of solitude. This is a shameless snippet of Bruno Campello de Souza’s excellent answer. This is a graph of the Big Five personality traits as function of IQ.  The asset of the Big Five is that the traits selected are known to be heavily genetically determined. But another asset is that they have a strong correlation on MBTI - which is a much better known typification in everyday psychology. The graph demonstrates that extraversion and agreeableness are inversely related to IQ, while openness is positively related, and conscientiousness makes a ‘V’ curve. In the MBTI extraversion correlates to the E-I axis and the agreeableness on F-T axis. People scoring high on B5 ‘E’ are likely to be extroverts in the MBTI, and those scoring high on ‘a’ tend to be feelers in the MBTI. Openness correlates to the N-S axis on MBTI, and high score on Openness indicates intuition on MBTI. This would predict that INTJ and INTP would be over-represented among the highly intelligent. And that is exactly the case. Low score on agreeableness (being Thinker) also indicates lower scores on empathy and altruism. [Ayn Rand would love this discovery]. Having a low score on agreeableness is a two-edged sword. On the one hand it enables independent thinking and prevents herd-mindedness. On the other hand it makes you a bad schmoozer and bad on fitting in. And I myself noticed this herd-mindedness and its correlation on being part of a group and socializing - and how the most intelligent of my classmates tended to be unpopular like me - already as a kid. I also noted if you have low score on Openness (being S in MBTI), you are likely to be a bully. If you have a high score on Openness (being N in MBTI) you are likely to be a weirdo or a freak in the eyes of the other people. My childhood and youth were extremely lonely. I was an inch-treaded nut among metric bolts. Only sports - swimming - brought me friends and decent human relationships. But there is one sad fallacy, We think people are the same, and we tend to think everyone are similar as we are. My mom said me when I complained I was so different from the others “Honey, you are just similar as the other kids. Now be pretty and go playing with them.” I never figured out if she was clueless, stupid or just mean. Since intelligence usually means high scores on Openness and low scores on Extroversion and Agreeableness, it means highly intelligent people tend to think everyone is alike to them: tolerant, nice, kind, accepting of others, open-minded, liberal, magnanimous and smart. They aren’t. You very soon learn kids are mean, intolerant, cruel, petty, stupid, vindictive and frivolous. If you are lucky, you are left alone and experience the awful loneliness. If you are unlucky, you are singled out and bullied. The kids are small psychopaths and they eagerly tear you into pieces. You quickly realize that you are predestined to be alone. It isn’t your assumed lack of social skills. It is because of you being different. If you are lucky, you can find a group of kids or youth who are within your communication range and be likely to think like you, have interest in similar things like you, have hobbies like you, and understand your patterns of thinking. Lika barn leka bäst. For me, it was the swimming community. Swimmers - and other individual athletes - tend to be bright and smart, in contrast to team athletes. If an athlete is a bully, he is without an exception an ice hockey, football or some other team sport player. Did anyone say Dunning-Kruger effect? It is again another reason for the communication range issues. Because you are more intelligent than the others and you are simply different, it is YOU who is seen as the idiot, the stupid, the incompetent, the dullard. You are aware of your potential, but the other guys aren’t aware of theirs. And because they sorely lack talent, they are likely to overestimate theirs and underestimate yours. The situation is flipped over in a sick manner. If you are lucky, you are simply ousted off their companionship. If you are not, you get harassed and bullied. I have often been asked “why don’t I use my talent for the common good of the humankind” and “why don’t you help people with your gifts but you selfishly make your own life cosy and comfortable”. The reason is simple. Why would I aid my enemies? I know exactly what it is to be a subject of social exclusion. Why should I care a fsck of those people now? I rather live hedonistically and do things which are fun and insane in the same way, and rather socialize with my own two tribes than even try socializing with the normies. I have been told many enough times by the normies that I do not belong in. The life is simply too short to be spent on unsatistying or toxic relationships and companionships.

I personally feel lonely and alienated 99 percent of the time. Whether this is due to high intellect, your guess is better than mine. Most of my days are spent placating to the needs and wants of neurotypicals who look down on me. This is evident in my place of employment, and sometimes even in my personal life. It's easy to characterize a person as stupid from having limited exposure to them, yet it's not easy to see the person behind the shell. I've never felt like I truly belong in neurotypical society, and I attribute this to the fact that most of what we know as truth and acceptable (from a societal perspective) is dictated to us through the media, through our upbringings, and our respective communities. We are force fed our values and told that there is no other way of thinking, organized religion does this with an iron fist. When true and false become binary that's usually when I question things. Uniformity is a given in order to establish solidarity between peoples and communities, but when something deviates from the conventional "norm" that's when it threatens the fragile framework of that societal structure. Most people I meet on a daily basis think quite linearly, never posing questions, never questioning biases, never thinking objectively. When two individuals who have opposing perspectives meet I've noticed one of two things: 1. Both parties agree to disagree, and never bring said differences up again in conversation. 2. Both parties react with animosity towards each other and find it hard to reach common ground. However, there is a third approach, when discourse is done properly each party examines the fallacies and gaps in their ideologies and only then can they spot similarities with the other person and solidarity can form. But alas, on this age of egotism and anti intellectualism being "right" is more important than being empirical. I digress To answer your question, high intellect is something that is a double edged sword. The more curious you are the more you want to learn about the world, when you learn more about the world you shift your paradigms while others (quite often those around you) stay stagnant and fall to cognitive dissonance. This will leave the person who is learning and growing isolated and feeling alien.

Given evidence from some data of mine, I’d say “yes”. In a study with 1,383 adults from Pernambuco, Brazil, IQ was negatively associated to both Extraversion and Agreeableness.  However, the self-evaluation of social skills as a function of IQ for a similar group of 1,777 individuals showed the following pattern:  So, it would appear that, indeed, high Intelligence is associated to being alone more as preference than due to a perceived lack of social skills. One can speculate that the following mechanisms and processes might be at play: With a higher IQ, there is a tendency for a higher level of working memory and also long-term recall, as well as speed of processing, which grants the ability to generate more and better mental imagery, thereby creating an incentive for “daydreaming” or “zoning out” (think of having your own personal “mental holodeck”);IQ is, by definition, the capacity to deal with abstract thinking, making the intellectually gifted more prone to detach from concrete experiences;The things that many of the Gifted are most interested in are not the things that attract the vast majority of people, the same happening with their life and work experiences, so that the highly intelligent may not find much in common with the majority of people and vice-versa;Being a minority by definition, a relevant portion of the Gifted might be the object of prejudice, making them more prone to withdrawing from social interactions and/or being less inclined to be less empathetic or altruistic;The differences in the size and breadth of vocabulary between the Gifted and most people might make communication more difficult or cumbersome;The Gifted can, at times, become frustrated, impatient or irritated with the slower and/or more limited intelligence of normal individuals, something which can come from elitism, self-importance, sense of superiority and even Narcissism, but can also arise from honest exhaustion from continuously having to wait for, explain to, correct, and accept errors from most of the people one interacts with.A combination of the above things is possible, as well as other elements I have not considered. Remember that we do not even know how much the findings from Pernambuco, Brazil, can be extrapolated or not to other parts of the World. Like a lot of things in Human and Social Sciences: its complicated.

We have had experiences that others haven’t, and people don’t necessarily imagine the consequences of that. Often, we are put on a pedestal, which has some benefits, but is certainly lonely and puts us under pressure that we can’t escape no matter what we do later. Staying up there is difficult and lonely. Falling from grace is painful, earns us humiliation, and is usually still lonely, because you aren’t just welcomed back to the crowd. You’re still “that kid.” It’s great to be accomplished in school, unless you can feel the resentment around you, unless it makes you a target for expressions of resentment (bullying, teasing, intimidation, jokes, anger, sadness). It’s hard to laugh off even the mildest jabs when there’s this entire atmosphere of resentment hanging around you all day, every day. Other people tend to look at specific incidents and say, “hey, don’t worry, that wasn’t so bad!” How do you explain how hard it is to anticipate that people are gonna tease you or jokingly/not jokingly hate on you as soon as you get that latest test back, and the next test, and the next… How do you explain the pressure of knowing that your friend can get anywhere from a 70% to a 90% and not attract attention, but for you, anything less than 90% means ridicule from your classmates, and anything above that means resentment? My friend tried to tell me recently that I didn’t need to care, that I could have teased people back and no one would have hated me. For me to have believed that at the time I was in school, I would have needed to be a completely different person. Not everyone would have felt the same in my shoes, that much is true. Not every intelligent person even stands out in the first place! That doesn’t make my experience false, or my fault. The fact that I could have reacted differently doesn’t change the truth that I could and did sense resentment, that I did become a target, that I didn’t understand social rules well enough to figure out that I could tease people back, that the attention was painful even though I was proud of myself, because I never really knew when I would have to defend myself and/or comfort someone who didn’t do as well, because I personally hated to be the cause or prompting event for suffering. But even though I know my truth, I don’t know very many people who can relate. Without someone to say, “Aw, yeah, I totally know what you mean. When that happened to me, I —,” it‘s just difficult to validate myself, and that is what’s lonely about being intelligent. It’s what happens to intelligent people that makes (some of) them lonely, and also the scarcity of people who understand us. Hope that helps! Katie❤️⭐️

Yes. As long as we acknowledge that there exists a huge difference between being alone and being lonely and that even the definition of the term, being alone, may not be so obvious, especially here in the 21st century, then I would say that for a number of reasons, intelligent people are more likely to be alone. Intelligent people certainly have a much more difficult time finding people with whom they are intellectually compatible. Intelligent people also tend to be somewhat eccentric. They worry very little about conforming their behavior in order to meet the standards which typically define what is normal nor are they very much inclined to satisfy the expectations of those around them. So even when they find people with whom they may be intellectually compatible, they still need to be able to withstand each other's eccentricities. And then even if they found these other smart people whose eccentricities they could tolerate or even enjoy, intelligent people are rarely, if ever, bored enough to feel any great need to socialize, as the term is conventionally defined. As long as they have a good book with them or some easy access to the internet, intelligent people are very happy in the company of the endless number of writers with whom, in their own way, they regularly converse. And always having a cell phone in your pocket has made defining what it means to be alone much more difficult. The solitude one would experience inside a cave 50,000 years ago if you overslept and members of your clan went hunting and left you behind is not the same solitude as sleeping late on a Saturday morning say 30 years ago in an empty house with a telephone and television set, nor are these scenarios remotely similar to the so-called solitude one experiences today as long as that cell phone is in your pocket. So in the 21st century, if you want to obtain the attention of an intelligent person who appears to be alone, you may find yourself competing with Aristotle, the author of a classic novel, a challenging logical paradox, the news of the latest scientific discovery, the details of a relatively obscure battle fought during the Hundred Years’ War, or some story about living conditions in some remote part of Africa. But intelligent people can also be very curious about the so-called real world away from their books, where flesh-and-blood people dwell. And in their own way, intelligent people probably do enjoy socializing as much as most other people as long as they can talk about their own ideas or the ideas of other smart people. Intelligent people don’t much care about exchanging mundane biographical information, listening to gossip, or spending too much time evaluating the menu or decor of the newest restaurant in town. Because intelligent people tend to find nearly everything so utterly fascinating and so worthy of contemplation and discussion, intelligent people tend to prefer thoughtful and stimulating conversations about subjects that mean little or nothing to most other people, and in their less intense, less uptight moments, intelligent people probably do enjoy a little bit of small talk … as long as it’s not too small.

But thankfully, few of them succeeded and fulfilled their destiny before they went. :)  O, Father…We have your message and we will remember you forever!! So we ask, “Is this how they are rewarded for being an exceptionally good human being? How can they deserve such a horrible trial? It’s the greatest injustice of all.” Nature answers, “This is the price you pay for deviating from the norm and bending my rules.” And Nature warns, “I didn’t bring you here to evangelize the good from the bad, or adjudicate what is right or wrong, you are not the moderator nor the peacemaker, just follow the pattern, stick to the norms just like the rest and you’ll be fine, or else….PAY THE PRICE!!”. The question is… DO YOU AGREE WITH THIS POLICY OF NATURE?? Let me know.  Is it too difficult for us to comprehend that nature wants all of us to behave like foolish ignorant slaves, ruled by a group of elite?? And it’s going to do whatever it takes to get rid of anyone who comes forth to ruin nature’s cruel plan. So, let us detach our humanoid brains for a while and just Think!! Think!! Spiritually from a divine perspective. Why is there politics?? Why is there so much competition?? Why is there a social norm?? And who regulates it?? And who dictates our actions?? Why do we idolize good looking people and what defines attractiveness, does the definition comes inbuilt inside all of us?? Why do today’s celebrities wear outfits resembling antiquated royalty and why do some of us worship them like kings & queens?? If fashion, makeup and implants are a deception, why are we so obsessed with it?? Why do we succumb to the temptation of following others?? Why are social networks such a big hit?? Why do we spend more time adding strangers as friends on Facebook and less time making real friends in life?? Are all these nothing but taking unfair advantage of our evolutionary weaknesses for a few to profit in the name of ethic?? Why is it that when some animals kills to survive, we call it wild and barbarous, but when we kill to taste in a massive scale, we call it a tradition, and we embrace it?? Why is it that tradition is to be embraced for all and the few who questions tradition are declared as mentally unstable?? Are we the perfectly manufactured product of a perfectly sculpted environment?? and so on… Questions like these can make us shit our pants a little, and sure we can come up with a more technical answer to all these… But quite simply, in a philosophical way, I dare say that all of us has been blessed with the “genes of slavery”. To save us slaves from chaos, all of us. This is what evolution has done to us. Our world would’ve been even more chaotic and worse if this wasn’t the case.  I doubt that it’s a link, but rather a process, a cycle! Some of you might be able to connect well if you are already familiar with “Nihilism” and the philosophies of “Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche”. If at all, it sheds some light on why we have too many selfish, stupid people and too less geniuses today. Also, these concepts sort of explains why exceptionally intelligent people usually tend to suffer, otherwise I won’t be here writing an answer to help someone.  NATURE AT WORK!! POWERFUL!! STEALTHY!! CRUEL!! COMPLEX!! UNFAIR!! RIGHT?? And now, I fail to see the beauty in it as others might see.  But not aesthetically though. If we married Philosophy with Evolutionary Biology, this is how it will look like.  Being intelligent is not a curse, and if you’re emotionally intelligent as well, then, chances are, you are a very good and kind human being; the problem has to do when coping along with the mass inferiority in the social environment that surrounds the victim. It can be said that these complications wouldn’t have existed if all the others had the same level of intelligence. So screw them if they start mistreating you, it’s their fault, not yours. Hope some of these concepts are enlightening and helps you to look at the world with a new pair of eyes from now on. Sorry, it had to be a bit long. And if you’ve managed this far without skipping a part, it means you can absorb and perceive the ideas I’m projecting which you’re very attached to. That in itself tells how you can relate yourself to all these. Keep on going!! Share it and explain, if you know of people who needs to realize this before it’s too late for them. Help them!! Upvote, if this meant something to your life. And let me know what you felt after reading this. And remember, don’t beat yourself up or listen to the bullies. They are afraid of what they cannot understand. You are a gem, gifted with the power to change the world, don’t waste it. BE POSITIVE!! BE HAPPY!! And most of all… Thank you all for bearing with me :D   Coming from a guy who once suffered from anxiety disorder, ended up hypnotizing his psychologist, an aspiring philosophical writer, who’s obsessed with the nocturnal imaginations and hates the silliness of humanity. response.answer_text: Some of the answers here seem to be of the philosophy that loneliness stems from low EQ, and completely eschew analysis of other factors. I think this is generally an unconscious attempt to pretend everything is fine, as is generally the optimistic and human thing to do (though assuredly EQ does have something to do with it). For me, personally, that’s one of the things that make me lonely; a lot of people tend to go through life with a bit of wool or rose-colored-glass—of varied amount—over their eyes. Perhaps I am cynical, but I’ve seen some level of rational cynicism from all but one of the particularly gifted people I’ve interacted with; the world is objectively a harsh place, and when your mind connects more dots at a time, you’re more often reminded of the kids who pick on other kids, the war over mass delusion and global politics in Syria, the fact that we so happily plough forward into ecological destruction, and other tragedies of varied scale. Such a viewpoint, if frankly expressed, does not sit well with the average, neurotypical individual. Compound with this the fact that we do often get picked on a terrible amount (in the high ranges) if left amongst age-peers, and you get the potential for a fair bit of cynicism. Some do avoid it, but, in my experience, such avoidance is rare, and comes with unconscious blind spots in perception. Further, to be well matched in conversation, those on the higher end of the spectrum, perhaps 145 or 150 and on, really need to interact with people somewhat close in score. This does not mean they cannot extract value from interaction with other age-peers, but it does mean that they will miss out on a very significant fraction of meaningful interaction. Imagine if you were a great soccer player, and it was one of your greatest loves in life, but only one in two thousand people even played soccer, let alone well enough to make for a satisfying game. You’d be forever lacking a part of, what is for you, meaningful social interaction. If you don’t constantly mask your intelligence, people will often view you as a freakshow—sometimes in admiration, sometimes in disgust, sometimes in envy. None of the options above are enjoyable, and all feel isolating. All the cynicism I mention—and I only truly have reliable data for a non-random sample of n=5—may contribute to its own crimson-colored-glasses effect, but that’s a story for another answer. It may also be an exception rather than the rule, but I see a significant elevation of it and comorbid depression in the highly-profoundly gifted I’ve interacted with.

Intelligent people tend to be thinkers and sensory types (ex. listeners, observers). They are “wired” differently, going about their perception of the world in a different process than others, perceiving things as factual things with cause and effect. They may question even small details, with the 5 Ws (what/who, why, where, when, how), and try to gather contextual evidence to understand the bigger picture before acting (ex. speaking out). Other people tend to be so unpredictable that the intelligent person’s act of perceiving can get tired out trying to comprehend things, on top of controlling their imagination/assumptions from filling in for a lack of context, leaving them drained. They’ve learned from others’ mistakes. They might consider common activities done as a get-together as events that lead to mistakes. People might pressure them to conform a little to enjoy the get-together activities, by “switching off their typical brain process” or at least by “loosening up”. I don’t know if they can entirely do this, but it exposes them to an environment that they doubt is progressive or beneficial (significant risk of being detrimental). They might merely open up their comfort zone, lowering their guard, but their sharpened senses might still be active and notice things being too noisy, witnessing uncomfortably low standards of behavior, and/or observing some other quality (ex. healthiness). They might be too polite to point out how these issues affect them personally, and instead just refuse to accept further invitations. The brutal truth might be that they’re “too good” for others. They might have certain moral standards that keep them from being comfortable doing certain things. For example, they might be disinterested, or even appalled by the act of engaging certain common activities such as gossiping about other peers or celebrities, or venting about responsibilities, for the sake of improving one’s personal mood/tensions (includes drinking, or other ways to release anger or escape reality). Get them to speak about something more abstract, such as the big picture in politics (Saudi vs Iran, rather than about Trump’s last tweet), or events that deem action (anthropological global warming vs vegas shooting), and you might find out just how far you are from them—they might not shut up once talking about these subjects, and you might be totally lost or even embarrassed if you show how unknowledgeable you are about the topics at such a scale (by speaking out). This difference in moral standards may lead to hostile reactions, with some perceiving the intelligent person as looking down on them, perhaps acting “too perfect”, and possibly becoming the topic of gossip and venting, which increases the distance between people. With high enough moral standards, they might not be interested in socially accepted debauchery or go as far as avoiding the 7 deadly sins (including seeking attention and progressing social status). The process of making friends might be judged by how beneficial it all is. The chemistry to create a win-win situation, with a bond strong enough to be considered a friendship, is considerably rare for them. Intelligent people tend to wind up “bickering” with each other; they end up disagreeing over minor details, even if most of their knowledge base overlaps. If they specialize in different fields, they might just wind up as acquaintances that they can call up for expert opinions. The strength of these bonds are closer to respectful, than truly friendly. There’s a stereotype that says that everyone has a “stupid friend” and they’re no exception to intelligent people, being one of the rare compatible types. Heck, one intelligent person could be the “stupid friend” to someone even more intelligent. Deep down, almost everyone has a unique definition of what it takes to be considered a friend. Intelligent people might be more precise or sharply aware of certain factors, which determine success/compatibility rate. They can use level of personal trust to be the core trait of friendship, followed by personalized concern for each other. They could take that further, requiring a fine balance, where trust and concern levels are relatively equal as they gradually rise—attempting to rush things and placing too much trust in the other person unexpectedly might be detrimental to the relationship. They might require others to understand them as an individual. Perhaps, they might simply look for someone to bounce ideas off of. What they seek in a friend, can’t really be generalized, but there’s some cause and effect that can be correlated to intelligence, and common practices that almost all humans follow in making friends. Things very well might be link to the “stupid friend” relationship. I think that it’s unfortunate that due to the trends and conformity of society that peculiar traits, such as being types that want to stay by themselves, end up being loosely correlated to a certain group/classification. This is not a trait of intelligent people, but it can be a trait of another type of people. I’d guess that it might be a trait of sensitive unstable types, but even they might want some social stimulation from time to time. There are truly decent folk that are intelligent, that fit right in with society, as others have pointed out. There are others with such a trait of wanting to be alone, but they could be intelligent or not, and have a wide variety of reasons regarding why they have such a trait. A common reason for wanting to be alone could simply be due to society being harsh to them (ex. judgemental). An intelligent person might perceive things as being simpler, easier and less problematic if they’re by themselves, not willfully inviting the risk of trouble without any worthwhile benefit—they might’ve utilized such intelligence efficiently enough to be very self-sufficient.

YES. a resounding YES unintelligent people hanging around just waste our time and prevent us from accomplishing things we want to most intelligent people love spending time alone because their minds are occupied with things “normal” people would never or could never conceive of. Sad, but true. a lot of intelligent people prefer to be alone to being social. they realize the most popular person wins nothing in the end, just like the most wealthy wins nothing in the end, not even another minute of life. only truly ignorant people spend all their spare time and money at the bar, you know. all that benefits is the bar owner who pretends to be your friend to keep you coming in and paying their mortgage for them every month instead of buying a home of your own. they are charging you $2.50 - $5 for a beer that cost them less than 50 cents a glass. they are charging you $4 or more per shot that only costs them about 80 cents. they are charging you $4 or more for a mixed drink that cost them about 80 cents. only truly ignorant people buy bar owners a home in five years rather than buying one for themselves, but the truly ignorant don’t realize they are paying 5–20 times what the same drink would cost them at home just to have someone to sit with and talk to. if you believe bar owners are not opportunists taking advantage of other people’s ignorance and desire to have someone, anyone like them, they wouldn’t be in that business. believe me, no bar owner any of us knows isn’t well aware that they are making money by exploiting people’s loneliness and unhappiness and they do their best to sell you enough to make it so that you are paying $20 an hour or more just to sit in their bar. those that stay open on holidays only are open on holidays because they know the sad and lonely will be more self-pitying and willing to give them more of their money that day. that free turkey or ham they “have a dinner for those without anyone” for on holidays isn’t to benefit the lonely or sad, it is only to benefit them and get you to give them twice as much of your money that day as you did the day before.

I have read many Quora answers to the question “What are the signs that a person is intelligent?”and these answers with 2000 likes usually contain the sentence - They like to spend their time alone. My life experience, completely disagrees with this statement. When we think of intelligent, we think of people like Newton, Einstein etc. These people are not just intelligent, these are geniuses, they are like the extreme of intelligence. When you get to this level, may be the symptoms of ‘lone intelligent’ people might show up. But there are a lot of people, millions of people, who are highly intelligent, and who wouldn’t fit into this category of lone intelligent people. You can see highly intelligent Harvard graduates who also party a lot, you can see Doctor Mike, look at Oscar Wilde, Rimbaud, highly intelligent comedians, Natalie Portman. Some of the greatest tacticians in history were obviously not introverted. Alexander, Tamerlane, Gengis Khan were not spending time alone. Robert Greene said Napoleon had the most advanced technology of his age, he possessed a powerful supercomputer, his own mind. You can see all these socially intelligent Chess Grandmasters, whose livestream I watch time to time. They are certainly spending hours with each other and they are not spending ‘more time alone’. IM Sagar Shah who is also a CA, is sometimes streaming for 10 hours interviewing and teaching people. I am a medical student and I see a lot of people who absolutely hate being alone, who are party animals, and are very good at studies. Just look around. There are such people literally everywhere. I don’t think there is much relation between intelligence and extra/introversion. For me, intelligence has something to do with intellectual achievement, not with having a wide range of intellectual interests. I think people tend to confuse those 2. Just because you have a lot of intellectual hobbies, doesn’t necessarily mean that you are intelligent. You need to have some intellectual achievements, and I have seen many extroverted people beat even introverted people in this regard whether it’s in chess, in studies etc. I think wanting to spend time alone is not because of ‘intelligence’ but rather a socialization need. Introverts have a more sensitive nervous system so they are bombarded with stimuli, so they need to take break from this constant barrage of emotions and ideas. But this has nothing to do with- whether they can solve problems quicker ( Physics, Biology, IQ, Maths, Organizational problems etc etc) , understand concepts very quickly, can write great poems, get their seat in medical school. You need to do such things to show me that you are intelligent and I have seen many extroverted people accomplish these things. So my life experience disagrees with that statement. If you believe I wrote of one these things, then you haven’t understood what I wrote- Introverts are not intelligentOnly extroverts are intelligent.

I've been a member of a group for parents of talented/gifted kids for a decade now. One thing that is given about people one or more standard deviations from the norm in IQ is that the further their IQ is from the norm, the more unique they are and different than others even of the same IQ. Even if they can find someone as intelligent, that person might be passionate about math, while they are passionate about art or botany. A similar IQ doesn't mean that they have a meeting ground. Through this group, I've learned much about the many different ways giftedness can manifest itself. Many people are more sensitive than others, simply because we catch on to what's going on around us much faster than others. We can see the fleeting look of dismay on someone's face and realize that the person with the quick smirk is manipulating the situation. Or we can see patterns in a series of events, and realize where something is heading a long time, sometimes months, before others do. And if it's not a good place and upsets us, we can either try to alert others and be called kooks if we don't have a degree in that area (or sometimes even if we do), or we can keep silent but upset, and seem to be inexplicably moody.  Another thing is "excitabilities". This has the same root cause. The highly-intelligent can see connections and meanings in things that most don't notice. So the highly-intelligent 10-year-old is jumping up and down with excitement while waiting to cross the street because he's just realized he saw a rare cloud formation or a rare bug, and those around him think his parents failed in disciplining him so he's acting like a 4-year-old.  Another thing is asymmetry in development. You may have a 6-year-old who is doing algebra, but who is struggling with reading. Or a 10-year-old who is writing a wonderfully grown-up novel, but who can't remember how to borrow to do simple subtraction. As the child grows, these tend to even out somewhat, but you'll still see adults of very high IQs who are groundbreakers in one area, like physics, but average in many others, and even struggle in a few areas (scheduling their time; have trouble with spelling). So mostly, the highly intelligent, if not also autistic, try to keep social interactions to pleasantries and try to appear as others. If we can find someone who shares an interest, even if that person doesn't have the same ability, we can develop a real friendship with that person, even if it doesn't allow us full range of our own abilities. For those who are open to it, we can learn things in those friendships and from those people.  The dream is the off chance we ever meet someone who shares both our interest and our ability. Hopefully we also hit it off personally. There's high incentive on both sides to make such a friendship work.

For a relatively long time I thought so. Until I’ve started meeting really smart people. Not “straight A’s in high school” smart. “Smart” is vague term. “Intelligent” is much more useful, and intelligence is literally capability of solving problems. All kinds of problems. Doing math. Learning languages. Writing poetry. Composing. Painting. Meeting people and having a conversation. There are two types of intelligence-related bullshit: the first is about how a single number (IQ) can determine your potential in life and the second is about different types of intelligence. People want to be able to say “I have low emotional intelligence, but I am good at this or that, so I am smart and that’s why the cruel world doesn’t accept me”. The reason why smart people spent a lot of time alone is that they are busy. The smartest people I know work very long hours, deeply immersed in their projects they are so passionate about. But oh my, would you look at them during the weekend. They are the most interesting and engaging people you’ll ever see. When you are having a conversation they don’t talk to you about TV, weather, Kardashians, heck, they can’t be lonely because they are so interesting! Not being arrogant and self-centered helps very much. Intelligent people don’t repel others being obsessed with themselves, they are generally very humble. Which makes them even more attractive. That being said, sometimes a person makes a choice to be alone. A famous example is Paul Dirac who was extremely secluded. But this is a rare case. For every Dirac there’s one Feynman who was life of the party and one Schrödinger who was one helluva womanizer. From what I’ve seen, being intelligent reduces your chances of being lonely by far. Not being lazy and putting your brain into work outside your comfort zone? That’s where the real adventures begin…

I am intelligent. I consider myself gifted. I showed potential for gifted programs when I was younger, but did not apply myself. My parents let me decide how much academics mattered to me. When I was in pre-school through high school, and my first college, the academics were not my top priority but a requirement. I graduated at good ability but did not develop my fullest potential. Now I have applied myself and gotten into a competitive program and university with high expectations at Stanford. I have always preferred to play with my peers, and engage with interesting activities and discussions, not always related to intellectual matters. I enjoy working with people much older than me, with subject matter expertise and professional development. I find their mindset is more appropriate for responsibility expected of work. I have found that I learn best under the direction of field leaders, and persons with high meritocratic credentials. But owing to my parent’s decision to let me decide my own academic study, I enjoy studying alone. I prefer to learn alone, with resources I choose, and practice on activities that I am interested in. I learn best this way, without too much person interaction, and the social nuances that go along with learning in a school or work environment. However, if there is one environment I do excel in with people, it is a design style or acting environment. This suits my style best, because it has the least social conditioning, and gets straight to the matter and problem to solve. It does not specifically narrow out specific roles and social functions. Most of this style of learning is a preference and is traceable to personality preference, such as the Big Five Inventory or more common personality inventories. The tendency is specifically called introverted preference, as well as less emotional or social interaction preference.

Intelligent people are occupied in their own minds planning creative things they can build, and working out solutions to things, because intelligence is a function of creativity. To me an intelligent person is merely a person who has a personality which finds satisfaction in creating things, and in early childhood learned how to make distinctions because those are the tools necessary to create anything. The creative process is solitary and not a team effort. Also well being is found in interactions with media like music because of the emotional satisfaction of experiencing creative things which one can only experience by yourself. That is aesthetic pleasure, and is a reflection of that person’s values. Values are a function of that person’s temperament and personality characteristics. Otherwise media products documentaries or maybe books and sources of knowledge so they can understand the world better and not make errors or mistakes. I have a high IQ and I feel a responsibility to understand the world and not make mistakes which might harm others. I want to not commit violence like participate in wars if they are not justified. If a war happens I want to understand how and why it came about. However if there is a situation where violence will prevent harm to others then I want to know it, and I want to understand what I am doing completely. I’m not satisfied with the beliefs and assumptions of others. Frankly there is little I can learn from anyone who is not an experienced expert on some topic. I don’t need a lot of social interaction. If I choose to be with someone it’s for a purpose. People who know me say, “Michael doesn’t wake up in the morning or do anything unless there is a reason.” There is so much to be done in life to build my own well being and make responsible decision so i don’t harm others that there’s not enough time to learn all the things I need to know, and do all the things I need to do. I am more friendly and helpful than most people but I don’t need the company or approval of anyone. I care about people and want them to succeed, but I don’t accomplish anything for them or myself by sharing their lives. People who need the company of others often do so because they are bored and need the stimulation of interaction with others. As for myself even when I am alone I never feel as though I am alone. I never feel as though I am by myself. I feel as though I am always, constantly in touch with consciousness outside of myself, and that consciousness is higher than I am, and that all persons are meant to live with that consciousness first and do not really have a genuine need for other humans unless there is a specific purpose for that interaction. That is a metaphysical explanation but it is the way I perceive it. I am never really alone. This is an unconventional answer but it’s simple facts. Ask an autistic savant if they feel as though they are alone. They appear from the outside to be alienated but they are not. What they describe is having information and data pouring into their minds from outside of their minds. They are constantly interacting with creative forces outside of themselves which give them factual information. Any artist will tell you that they are accessing inspiration and “data” from outside themselves during the creative process. Paul Simon says that when anyone writes a song that they are not creating the song but that the song already exists and all they are doing is tuning into reality so they can access and reveal what already exists. That is how he creative process works, and it is not solitary but involves interaction with that which exists outside of ones self but which does not involve other humans at that time. Then afterward it can be illustrated to other humans and you can transmit to them the emotions and values conveyed in the creative process from outside.

There is some evidence that intelligent people are more likely to want to be alone. For instance: People With Fewer Friends Tend To Be Intelligent: Study I think this is quite understandable in a number of different ways. For one thing, if you’re someone who likes to think things out a lot, it’s generally going to be easier to do that alone than around people. So arguably the question is a bit like asking “Why do mountain climbers tend to hang around mountains?”. Perhaps intelligent people are hanging around the solitude they need to think. Then there’s the fact that anyone who thinks a lot in a detailed way (which presumably goes hand in hand with intelligence) is liable to find it frustrating to be around the majority of the rest of the world, who are less into abstract analysis. Studies find that intelligence is correlated with openness to experience and to ideas. So someone who would like to discuss and analyse various ideas from various points of view might find it frustrating to hang around with people who are less into that and adhere more to the “spade is a spade” school of thought, or who are more likely to have fixed opinions even in the absence of evidence. I’d like to think of myself that I could be quite OK company for some hyper-intelligent professor character. I like to listen to different points of view and look at things in various different ways. But if this hypothetical professor were to head out to the local bar, he or she would likely encounter a relative surplus of strongly-held simplistic opinions and a deficit of careful reasoning. A return to the comfort of books and solitude might seem quite appealing.

If you’re talking about a Mensa group meeting then no. If you’re talking about a remedial math class in high school then yes. I will make the conext Canada in Toronto since that is where I live and the only place where I have a shred of credibility in providing this answer :-) Intelligent people I take to mean those who have above average problem solving skills, memory and insight into consequences of their actions. The last qualifier is crucial because I believe that alone is why the answer will tend to be yes. An average person will likely go out to a club, have some drinks or something else recreational then party hard. There are all kinds of potential negative consequences to that sequence of behaviours that the average person either is unaware of or chooses to ignore, the least of which is a hangover. Someone who thinks about consequences will not ignore what could go wrong and with usually try to reduce those outcomes or avoid them. That leads to choosing to not go out or go in a very restricted fashion. I.e. they volunteer to be the designated driver or only take enough $$ for 2 drinks and cab fair for example. Self-controlled behaviour is very admirable when it achieves something like a sports victory or military victory or business victory. Self-controlled behaviour that results in less “fun” or less risk is generally not admired and often ridiculed. “Two drinks?!? Duuuude I had 4 before I came here, take the stick out man and live a little!” An even better example is jaywalking across even a mildly busy street. The highest risk, which might be very tiny in the right circumstances, is your death from collision. The benefit is in many cases you save about 5 minutes of time not waiting for a crosswalk light to change. Thousands of people make that choice every day thinking nothing of it. Yet a few of those people die - they risked their entire lives for 5 freaking minutes of time!!! And those unlucky few lost… So people who lack self-discipline, either willingly or unknowingly, rarely admire people who have the intelligence to see potential dangers and avoid them. And that tends to be because the average person doesn’t “see” those risks or thinks they are so small that they are not worth considering. It also happens from a kind of ego defence because the average person is having fun and is emotionally incentivized to defend what they enjoy to avoid feeling bad about their actions. Almost all people have rose coloured glasses from birth - humanity is very positive oriented especially about ourselves. We routinely overestimate our capabilities and underestimate the risks. Until a life experience knocks those glasses off, most of us tend to live life without much worry. So the intelligent person acting in their own risk adjusted best interest will likely experience fewer social environments where they can meet a mate. They will probably be more restrictive in their choice of mate which adds up to a higher likelihood of being alone.

Quora is rife with these kinds of questions, and they are nonsense. For some reason, this platform has become a beckoning stage for egotists. I’m going to go against the grain here, and risk being viewed as someone who is hateful of people who tend to keep to themselves; I am not. These kinds of question, even just by being asked then treated seriously, promote such a stupid set of assumptions, void of any kind of nuance that the real world is actually composed of. People who are inept at socialization will sometimes rationalize it as some new-fangled positive, and so this stereotype of “quiet people are the intelligent ones” is perpetuated. Similar to the way arrogant people won’t say they’re arrogant, but will say they “tell it like it is, and people are uncomfortable with that.” Now, I’ve met quiet people who will state honestly “Yea, I’m a shy person, and that’s something I’m working on.” — I think that’s honest, admirable, and just nice. So, I’m not saying it *all* “loners” who make these backwards-rationalizations. And one more important clarification, is that I’m not saying all “lonerism” is borne out of social ineptitude. Some people just like their own company, and that’s just fine. It’s kind of lame if you’re out with your friends, and you hide-away into the corner of the room contemplating your own intelligence as an alternative to confronting your own social insecurities, but that’s a different thing. Sometimes people just want to hang-out away from the crowd, and they won’t always be formulating the next Grand Unified Theory; most the time, they will not be. I just hate this kind of self-aggrandizing BS; and this is as a person who tends to keep to themselves. It denigrates collaboration, and working with others is a kick-ass thing to do. As a counter-example to the (false) premise of this question (i.e. “Intelligent people always keep to themselves.”), take Paul Erdös. Very smart dude, would wander from Uni-to-Uni just to meet & collaborate with new people. Solved more complex math problems in his lifetime than the number of tips you’ll solve for on the bill.

Interesting range of answers!  The short answer?  Si!  My life is NOT one I would recommend to the faint of heart!  My close friends, colleagues, siblings, professors, musicians/artists see me much the same way: "a freak of nature".  Feverish early reader, I loved everything: math, science, history, music, poetry (eventually, political activism).  Progress was decimated by brutal parental alcoholism & dysfunction. To survive, I escaped at 17, discovering the "clown-self" within me, becoming a 'working clown' for over 30 years, doing pre-school's 'greatest hits' on mandolin for delighted children at parties, hospitals & cancer wards.  I worked at NBS (now NIST), attended community college, did music, drugs, chess tournaments, and Spacetime Physics.  Pursuing a dream to attend UC Berkeley, I drove 3000 miles to Berkeley in 1978, lived in my car for half a semester studying linear algebra to enter UC Berkeley as a math major on full scholarship, graduated, became a skilled carpenter, financed a work-year in war-torn Nicaragua (1985), worked on a health center in a war zone, got caught in a 6-day Contra attack; returned in '86 to attend graduate school, taught math for a quarter century, all the while running chess clubs, and still do.  I chose not to have children--for many philosophical & practical reasons.  I have loved many great women.  Parting was painful.  I feel lonely at times, but I chose solitude.  Alas, I am happy with my life, full of adventure and excitement.  I live facing the Pacific Ocean on a coastal mountain.  My life consists of many loving 'extended families'.  The short answer is "Si, pero no hay alegria sin dolor"!

For me it is three reasons. The first is the rarity of finding others on your level. I am in the top 1%. That means out of every 100 people I meet, there will be one that is on my intelligence level. Could take meeting 300 people before I fine one person on my level due to the way statistics work. I have eclectic tastes and interests. That means that even I meet that one in a hundred person, odds are that he or she will not be into amateur radio, shooting, and collecting knives. Lastly, is that I do not need the company of others to feel good about myself. I do not need their validation. I know who I am and what I can do. I also am not a follower. I lead. If the group wants to see movie X and I do not, I will not go with them for the sake of the friendship. If I do not feel like going to one of their parties, I will not go. Only doing things I want to do does not make lasting friendships in my experience. I enjoy being on my own. I travelled all over the world on my own. I worked from home on my own. I have had a very successful career and personal life, on my own. Friends tend to bring their drama into your life. They can also hold you back at times. Often what you want goes against the majority vote of a group. I prefer to live my life on my terms. I do have friends scattered all over the country. They are like we are, gypsies moving every few years. Once in a while we move near each other and start seeing each other again. I do not get upset if they do not call me regularly and they are the same. Most people think there is something wrong with being a loner. They think we should be like them and have a lot of friends whose lives they get involved in. I am fine on my own. I have done well on my own. I have plenty of hobbies that do not require anyone else to participate in them. I do socialize with my wife’s friends when we get together a few times a month for dinner or cake and coffee. That is enough for me. The husbands are all 8 years older than me and I have to play the conservative person in front of them. My wife’s friends would desert her if they knew she was bi. They are religious and we are not. Still, we socialize. I do enjoy our time together and the fact that they never ask anything of me. :)

In addition to Jim Davis excellent answer I’d like to add that smart people often come to conclusions and hold view that are not socially popular. Even stating this possibility is likely to be unpopular as you can see from the ratio of upvotes to views on this post. Nevertheless, it means that highly intelligent people are often avoided or need to be guarded and can’t just say what they believe. In the past those unpopular views that might make an intellectual unpopular might be votes for women, emancipation of slaves, not persecuting on the basis of sexuality or willingness to entertain ideas like evolution or of a non-geocentric universe. It won’t make this answer popular at all - every society like to think they have all the answers and are ‘right’ - but there are plenty of similarly unpopular views that we should discuss and consider today, but to even mention them would create the same persecution that intelligent people have always faced. So intelligent may form these from clear, well thought out principles consistent with a high ethical and moral position, but other people may jump to conclusions without understanding or fully considering there real reasons. Often they come to a truth which is not palatable, not what they would have chosen it to be on emotional grounds, but is still, to the full extent of their understanding, the truth. This sort of truth is often different from beliefs strongly supported by popular wisdom - which tends to unthinkingly celebrate the Zeitgeist - the current set of undeniable misconceptions. This makes it very difficult for them to be open about their feelings or beliefs or even calmly discuss this that they find interesting without being subject to bigoted attack and even hatred. I can see this happening all the time to highly intelligent people who I know, perhaps the most intelligent.

Everyone is intelligent. People with a mental disability can sort recycled materials, can laugh, feel, see, hear & cry. If you are alive you are intelligent. I believe we are created human beings of God. God is all we need to face another day. But it is not good for humans to be alone, we are designed as social creatures. We are designed as male and female to join as one and have offspring. We are to nurture and train our children. We have different languages and cultures to remind us that there is only one wise God and father of all. I grew up on a farm with wide open spaces with more animals, birds and insects & flies than people. I would dream as I walked behind the cows and milled the grain. It was a simple life of solitude with much thought, family and love. I was happy and helpful. Then I studied mathematics & physics. I observed nature from the classroom. However, science did not teach me about love, it just ‘was’. It ‘was’ amazing, it ‘was’ powerful, it ‘looked’ smart. Then I did further study in medical physics and worked in a radiotherapy treating cancer patients. I realized that people still died despite how much smart science we have. I realized that the head clinicians and professors made dumb personal health choices. They were human too. I realized that a person could be highly intelligent in one area and dumb in many others. I realized that an eccentric person is not necessarily an overall intelligent person. Then I started my own businesses, where you have no government grants, no funding other than your own sweat. No annual leave, sick leave, holiday pay, time in lieu (I thought that was ‘time in the loo’), conference leave, sabbaticals, 9 day fortnights, extended lunch breaks, overseas conferences (with 1 day conference and 6 days tourism). No government or employer gave us anything, we were on our own and had to believe in ourselves, we had self-respect. But we also had a dream bigger than ourselves. Immediately we commenced employing. I never realized that over the next 15 years we would employ over 100 people and have 80 percent of them not with us today. That really bothered me as they say you know you are doing something right when people follow. But a good friend of mine reminded me that not even Jesus could keep all his 12 disciples. So to answer your question; I would have to say no, real intelligent people are real people - they are real to how they were created as social people, lovers and givers. You can’t give with nobody around and you can’t receive when nobody is around. Let’s remember this Christmas that God gave himself for us that we may live eternally. That should inspire you & I to ‘go on’, live without fear and live with purpose and gratitude towards others. Until you & I can overcome death, we can’t be God. But we can be like God, we can love. What is love? God is Love.

Yes, both by choice and by chance, but that doesn't mean they are lonely. Their brains are wired in a way that they cannot explain, and sometimes they can't convey their thoughts to others because of that, making a lot of conversations for them seem futile, since they don't see the other person grasping the point, and don't have the energy or the means to explain it. Other thing that happens is that when they try to enter in a relationship with people that can't cope with their speed of thought they often alienate them or resent them for feeling smothered and not having free time for themselves and their thoughts, since the partner wants to do things together (this happens a lot to me). This leads to a lot of fights. So in the end they prefer to be alone and focus on things that gives them pleasure, often their own projects. Also being around them can be a huge burden since they have a lot of extreme opinions and don't restrain them in a relationship, and not a lot of people can handle it (i am in favor of euthanasia, death penalty, aborption and against equal universal vote, just to name a few). It is good to notice that a lot of these people are misjudged when they are young as being sociopaths or autists (I was tested for both) because of this isolation from others and refusal in engaging in normal social gatherings, and they can become agressive or sad because they think people are mistreating them. Some of them eventually realize that social interactions is a science in some form, and eventually decide to tackle their issues, by studying social sciences like psychology, economy, PNL or micro-expressions. They can become quite charismatic and charming when they do that, and even turn their new found hobby in a profession and be quite skilled (I am a product manager focused on user growth), but in the end they always need some alone free time since the first issues always appear, and they cannot sustain huge discontinuous amounts of social interaction.
