Its not all intelligent people who like to be alone, but intelligent people do tend to be more introverted from my experience. I can only speak for myself, and I will say I was discussing this very topic the other day with a close friend. See, I am very introverted and my friend is also. We were discussing why it is introverted people seem to be more extroverted when around other introverted people. We came up with the joking answer that introverted people are really extroverts, we just don’t like stupid people and since most people are stupid we seem like introverts. Now of course this isn’t the actual answer, most people aren’t stupid. Intelligence comes in many varieties, one person can suck at math but be an amazing writer and another person can barely spell but is amazing at math. Another person could suck at both math and language but be able to completely disassemble and then reassemble any piece of machinery you put in front of them. If you judge a fish by how well it can climb a tree of course it’s going to fail. That being said, it does seem that introverted people just prefer the company of a small group of very close friends they share many interests with instead of the more extroverted approach of having many casual friends you share a few minor interests with. In places of larger populations, you’ll often see large enough groups of introverts that you wouldn’t be able to tell they’re introverts. More people in an area means you’re more likely to find people that share a lot of your interests, so even if you’re an introvert finding like minded people you don’t mind spending time with isn’t going to be very difficult. In smaller population areas, you’ll often see introverted people doing things alone and be quite content to be alone. I live in a more rural area, I have one person locally I consider a good friend. There’s a couple of people I consider casual friends, and being a small town a lot of people know me and I have the occasional brief conversation in passing here and there, but I do most of what I do alone. Fortunately with the internet, you can find people who share all sorts of varied interests and it’s a great tool for introverts like me to make good friends and also have solitude. I think honestly the biggest different between an introvert and an extrovert is that introverts prefer quality over quantity.

I’m not sure this is always true, but in my experience I tend to use more complicated language because I have a broad vocabulary. I don’t use words to impress others, but to communicate precisely, which is why I like writing. I’ve noticed some people will take offense when you use a word they’ve never heard, as if you are trying to impress. So, that annoys people. Then instead of communicating accurately (my goal) I’ve in fact accomplished the opposite! It took me much longer than in should for an “intelligent person” (me) to figure this dynamic out. I never gave this issue much thought, as I’ve become used to being in “another world” most of the time (no idea if this is related to intelligence) until my husband, who by all measures is very bright, told me he often doesn’t talk much because people aren’t interested in his answers. I’ve noticed that what he does is give a very short answer or a long analysis, and in the latter case people don’t really want to hear a long analysis. I find his insights very interesting, and by pure happenstance have married someone who I enjoy talking to. So was somewhat perplexed that his conversational style seems to alienate people. He’s also very likable, I mean has a likable face and pleasant personality. After some reflection, I realized that his conversational style alienates people because they’ve never thought about what he’s saying and/or it’s too much work/inaccessible and/or the technical language used and/or the complexity of the argument itself. I know many intelligent people who are highly social, but they do generally tend to socialize with each other - similar to the way people of particularly professions, such as PhD level and MD level, tend to socialize with others of the same “status.” It’s just more comfortable to talk to someone who understands and is interested in what you’re saying.

Love this thread! It really speaks to my experience. I’ve been alone most of my life. I have always had the kind of mind that absorbs little bits of information and remembers them. I call this a Jeopardy mind (as in, you know so much, you should go on Jeopardy). I’ve also always known, or felt I have known, when I was right about those little bits of information. It was never arrogance on my part, simply a certainty that I knew what I knew. As a girl and young woman, I was frequently counseled to “play stupid,” because “men don’t want girls who are smarter than they are.” I always wanted friends and was fascinated by other people. In high school I usually had friends, too, most often a best friend within a very satisfying social group. But the close friendship within this group usually lasted only a year. Then the group sort of fell apart once we went off to college. In college I loved living in a dorm. There was always someone to talk to and share day to day lives with. I still am at my best socially when I can do that. I’ve often found it difficult to communicate with other people. I just don’t seem to think the way many other people do. I sometimes have felt like an alien dropped into a world I was not able to understand. I’m much more at peace with all this now. I have much greater insight into - and acceptance of - everything that has shaped who I am. I have been very satisfied in my worklife and continue to find other interests I am passionate about. And I have cultivated a sense of humor - I grew up in a family that had none. I am very happy that women and girls are growing up today in a society becoming more tolerant of intelligence and talent in women.

Yes and not. Intelligent people are lonely because it is difficult for them to find people that can fulfil their interests. And this is an interior behaviour touching more people than others think. To be alone doesn't mean not to have others around, but not to have a profound relationship. Take into consideration that there are very intelligent people on the "social" side of the spectrum (not only the math geeks are the intelligent ones), that know how to work with groups and make them to perform better than others, but that in their personal life they have no partners. But when a "real" partner appear, this loneliness gives space to a deep relationship. We humans, anyway, have been designed to be social beings. And there is some type of "partitioning" that can be developed with age, because the lonely people realises that "some" interests will be for them alone and no others will be able to match their focus or their speed when working them. However, other interests can match easier other people's thinking, opening them more interaction paths that were expected on early years. So yes, you can have a relationship and to have space for you alone, for you to develop your special way of thinking. Is it easy to find that "partner"? Not always, but current technology open new paths to arrive to others. Before was needed to send a personal letter, traveling months to arrive to an individual, but today on seconds it is possible to find information about thousands. So, humanity evolves in interesting ways.

This post connects deeply to my inner core of experiences. I feel as though whenever I speak to express an opinion, word of advice, momentary question, or in any means provoke a discussion about life, philosophy, wisdom, understanding, intelligence, or anything that is not considered humorous, rhetorical, anecdotal, professional in manner, or popular within the colloquial modality of thought, then it is 99.8 percent of the time neglected and detracted by others. And yet most the time even when that uniquely distinguished moment of interest does occur by someone who genuinely wants to listen and put thought into the conversation, the expression of ones words feel forced and the effort expelled fails to promote a feeling of gratitude and overall reciprocity of value exchanged between one another. The initial discussion of openness then transmutes into a monologue or rather a THESIS vs ANTITHESIS type dialogue and the channel for connection and any feeling of embrace becomes severed. Therefore, the one wanting to share in the conversation feels neglected and inevitably develops a behavior of discretion, humility, simpicity of thought, and will respond in favor of solitude over social engagement to mitigate these feelings of disconnection with others. Yet from this propensity towards a path of solitude, introspection, and intrinsically valued interests we still have this compelling feeling of catharsis to share with others in a careful or daring fashion. So, in summation based on my own empirical analysis, I would infer that those who possess higher levels of intelligence and training of mind will genuinely have a greater inclination towards spending time alone or with fewer people than the opposite of several or many. However, that being said, I am also convinced that this is primarily determined by ones choice of personality and attachment with others. For example, if you are one who can enthuse the majority of people to listen to you through wit, sarcasm, story telling, and other ways of persuasion and connective vibes then you have a higher capacity to thrive in both atmospheres. This would then depend on ones choice of habit.

Solitude, or being alone, is an individual choice, not a societal imposition. And it is certainly not an ensign that is assigned to ‘intelligent people,’ or to any particular group. We all suffer isolation in life and thought, when we do not subscribe to the values, beliefs, or actions of the hoi polloi, but how we choose to deal with this isolation will determine the liklihood and degree of our (self-imposed) solitude. While it is true that intelligence (depends on how this is defined), which is generally defined as the ability to process intellectually in a higher or more sophisticated realm, will necessarily be accompanied by its share of isolation in thought, it does not follow that persons at that level must be cast into solitary confinement. And if they are, then that is undoubtedly done by individual choice. Society dictates how it prefers its members to think and act, but only the individual member can decide how they will respond to such ushering. Yes, while we may have agreed to give body and soul to God and government, we still retain sovereignty over volition will. I think the great ones, from Socrates, to Gandhi, to Martin Luther King exemplified the viability of this. They also showed that intelligence is not just the acquisition of knowledge, but also the application of it, and one without the other is like Obama without Biden…..but let’s not digress. In both ancient and post-modern societies, quantitative methods are used to measure intelligence, and I am not convinced that these indicators are real, as they are socially constructed values. Moreover, they do not take into consideration that the ability to function at an elevated cerebral capacity is relative, and can be applied to a large spectrum of subjects, which do not fit squarely into the line-up of those conventionally used by IQ assessors. Artistic and creative abilities, for example, has never been included in any measure of ‘intelligence,’ yet it is a primary and direct functionality of the cerebral cortex (the storehouse of intelligence), and does not operate in isolation, but instead, works inextricably and organically in integrated brain processes (as does its counterpart, reason and rationality). And the exclusion of this area from the IQ determinator thus diminishes and disqualifies more than 60 % of the human population. Clearly then, the assessment of intelligence is relative, and what is considered intelligent in one society will vary geographical and culturally. So the measure that is today universally imposed is in itself an apparatus for insulation and segregation, and is a function of social organisation. Therefore, it is a societal inference and premise that ‘intelligent’ people should be singled out (for their own good, or the good of society); however, it still remains an individual choice to accept this distinction. Now let’s look at this issue from another angle: if axiomatically, intelligence is the ability to process cogently and critically not just in the domain of cognition, but also in the sphere of meta-cognition, and apriori, that would mean then that such a person is exceptionally gifted in higher analysis and reason, yes? And if this is so, then a truly intelligent person should be able to not only figure out the pedestrian nuances of societal behest, but also to suss out, and make choices that benefit their general health and well-being, right!? After all, intelligence is a responsibility, and the first task of any reponsible member in society is to evaluate and negotiate their own meaningful contribution to self and society. And an individual who follows slavishly the urgings and inculcation of society, is neither an intelligent nor a meaningful participant…...am I alone in this one?? The liklihood of lonliness then is an individual decision, and the statistics are dependent upon individual will. Therefore, if it happens that an individual decides (for their own reasons, perhaps even to reject societal norms) that being alone or in a camp with other like-minded individuals is the optimum environment to promote their (or societal) interest, then that is a conscious choice, and is neither a social prescription nor a proscription. Yes, perhaps the choice is influenced by societal prejudices and or pressures (or even their own ambit)…….but it is still a conscious, volitional choice!

I would not say "alone", maybe I would say "sad"... Loneliness being the undesirable byproduct of sadness. The problem with intelligent people (I know because I happen to be one...) is we tend to believe our own rationalizations. Here is the process: A situation happen, involving someone or notWe process it through different angles until we find an angle (or story) that suits usWe are smart so we find 101 ways to make that particular story "true"Since we are smart, we know how to convince people that this particular story is TRUE.Then, people around you start to sing YOUR song. Not because they have bad intentions. Generally, it's quite the contrary.At that point, there's (almost) no return. You start to become sad. Of course you don't call yourself that, you prefer "cynical".And now the worst happens. People don't stick with cynicals. They listen to them until someone or something else catches their attention... and there you go, you are alone...So from my point of view, loneliness is just a side result that you get when you are just plain sad.  Why are we sad? I'm not talking about regular sadness that we all feel several times a week. I'm talking about chronical sadness that we prefer calling "cynicism". I go back to the stories we tell ourselves. We made them up and take a stand to make them true. Unfortunately most people don't know how to tell themselves empowering stories, ones that make us happy and work deliberately toward long term goals. Being with a precious one surely is one of the top 3 that everyone on this earth would choose.  So here you go guys, tell yourselves positive and empowering stories.

This question could be broken out a bit more. Of course the first supposition is that intelligent people are lonely. Then there's a comparative aspect. Intelligent compared to whom? Lonely, compared to whom? Maybe, underlying this question, are several others: Are intellectual people lonely? Are introspective people lonely? Are reserved, non expressive, introverted people lonely? Here are some definitions from the Merriam-Westerner dictionary, at Dictionary by Merriam-Webster: America's most-trusted online dictionary, about the above. Of course all of the definitions are the property of the dictionary: Definition of intelligent 1 a : having or indicating a high or satisfactory degree of intelligence and mental capacity b : revealing or reflecting good judgment or sound thought : skillful 2 a : possessing intelligence b : guided or directed by intellect : rational Definition of intellectual 1 a : of or relating to the intellect or its use b : developed or chiefly guided by the intellect rather than by emotion or experience : rational c : requiring use of the intellect intellectual games 2 a : given to study, reflection, and speculation b : engaged in activity requiring the creative use of the intellect intellectual playwrights Definition of introspective : characterized by examination of one's own thoughts and feelings : thoughtfully reflective : employing, marked by, or tending to introspection As a student, he was very quiet and introspective. … encouraging a balance between the fast, upbeat songs and a band's more introspective side. —David T. Lindsay There's an interesting literature that suggests that when people are sad, they tend to pay attention to themselves. They become withdrawn and introspective and very aware of their body and their mind and not very aware of the external world. —Peter Salovey Definition of reserved 1 : restrained in words and actions 2 : kept or set apart or aside for future or special use Definition of introverted : having or suggesting the characteristics of an introvert; especially : possessing a reserved or shy nature typically with an inclination to solitude It frustrates and pains me to hear so many stories about how misunderstood and overlooked most introverted people felt when they were growing up. —Marti Olsen Laney —compare to extroverted There is something of an interlock between these five different sets of definitions. You can see a sort of human type of emerging. A person with high-end thinking abilities, coupled with a life based on an attempt at rationality, not emotions, introverted and not very sociable and not expressive. Character Types Go In and Out of Fashion People my age and older may remember a type of social presentation that was very popular in the 1950's. This was the horn-rimmed glasses, formal business suit, unemotional, discursive, professorial type of guy. These were exclusively males and almost always white. You can still see the old instructional films on the Internet. A gentleman of this type, sitting at a bulky wooden desk, discoursing in a deliberate, rational sounding way, about some topic. A relevant example, Control Your Emotions:  Actually, in this example, the professorial guy is not wearing horn rims. However he is wearing a distinctly 1950's pair of glasses. I think he is wearing a men's formal, white jacket, instead of a lab coat. Nevertheless he's got the style cold. Control your emotions, yes! It still resonates with me. Typically, when you were about to make a critical point, what later became a bullet in a PowerPoint presentation, you momentarily took your glasses off and then hit your audience with your moral-rational punchline. You would explain why Communism results from personal failings, like a fear of honest work and a Christian family lifestyle, and why the somewhat related male homosexuality was the result of a domineering, overprotective mother, plus a lack of sports training in childhood. Encouragingly, both could be cured by psychotherapy. So, how did these guys have a social life? Maybe in the staff room at the university or at the Protestant church of their choice. However, in those days of well-established gender-specific roles, it was the responsibility of the professor's housewife to be the emotion holder, ideal for a woman because of their limited intellectual capabilities. You could send the Little Woman out to socialize. I apologize for the tinge of nostalgia in this description. We Need Updated Horn-Rims For the Twenty-First Century Then, the hippies happened. Then, the self-satisfying yuppies and then the era of big hugs and the man bun. Now we lack a self-presentation style for guys who mostly think, or think they are thinking, aren't all that in touch with whatever other emotions they might be able to squeeze out and, just don't do big hugs. And then we have those women who really just don't have much in the way of domestic desires and get off on statistics and articles from Science Daily. The intellectual, not seething with passions, no I don't want to vent and I don't need yours either, self-presentation, has almost become the new, reprehensible lifestyle of our era, sort of a replacement for that good, old fashioned, evil Communo-homosexuality. Young, dance club women look at you fearfully. The guys with backward baseball caps see you as a personal insult. If you are older, the grandmother-aged women of your generation want so much to share their emotions about their grandchildren. Show them that you can't emphasize and they will head for the hills. Then there's that office. They want bonding and team building. You are surrounded by milennials who see their job time as hook-up heaven. Introversion and introspection turn into a disciplinary issue. When Do Friendships Become Obnoxious? So much of life is based on not thinking. It's not just intellectual laziness. It's because, without dreams and illusions, people can't live. Generally, you don't have to do too much thinking. An orderly daily life carries you on. Get up, make breakfast, walk to the bus stop, work, walk to the bus stop, go home. On the weekend shopping in your grubbies and your favourite sports bar. What if you started thinking about this? The barren, frozen bus stop two hundred kilometres south of the edge of subarctic Canada. The job means an abusive manager and no promotions, ever. When you get home your spouse has just come home from an equally unsatisfying job and is in no mood for family warmth. The bills to pay for your house in the suburbs, etc. If you were to start thinking too much about this you could render yourself distinctly unhappy, no team player, no joy at a hockey victory by the Ottawa Senators, no unrestricted faith that a Conservative Party majority government will resolve all problems. Your doubts will seep out to your facial expressions and body language. Your bros will quickly notice the change. They won't be your bros anymore. But, in reverse, you will know that your bros don't want to do much thinking. Their emotions are too often about false things. It doesn't matter whether the Senators win or not. It's just a sports game. And your bros don't want to know, look out your car window and your suburb has precious little going for it. Do your own thinking a little more and you can end up asking, why do I have friends like this? How Much Thinking Do We Need? If I had bros they might ask me, why think when you don't have to? Particularly in a well-off industrial democracy with an adequate social safety net, you can get by without needing to think all that much. You don't need to think about daily survival. The social safety net reduces the social problems you might feel compelled to think about. However, if you have a relatively high intellectual capacity, your mental wheels start to spin. Some intelligent people feel a compulsion to think. This compulsion may be the biggest passion in their whole lives. This passion is not easily shared. It can make a whole lot of people uneasy when they are with you. This passion can kill most of your chances for friendships, love and sex. Intelligent With None of the Above Of course, you can be intelligent with none of the above issues. You may be intelligent with regard to a particular thing, like being a really good club DJ, or predicting next year's bond market. After that particular thinking is done, you are quite able to shut it down and go on to big hugs. Love, Lots of Emotions and Passion, for Intellectuals and Introverts It's like being gay. The economics of social life for intellectual introverts are not favourable. In a Quora Answer a few months ago, I did a very rough estimate of how much of a base population is required to support a gay bar in any given, fully industrialized, democratic city. I came up with about 500,000 people for every single gay bar. This takes account of how many people in a given population are likely to be gay and how many are prepared to openly act it out. The economics for intell-introverts (How about “Intellovert” for a new Alt-Right insult word? An Intellovert is not the same as a Libertard.) are worse. “Gay” defines a fairly specific type of physical activity that requires one to seek out other Gays in order to do. Being an introverted, thoughtful, intelligent intellectual is a lot more diffuse. How large a population would it take to support an Intellovert bar, presumably a place with scientific lectures, analytical karaoke fun nights where you compete to sing out various intellectual constructs, nerd girl wet t-shirt contests, bouncers with horn-rimmed glasses, the whole works? If Ottawa had one I'd be down there like a flash. However, if one could conceptualize the details of such an establishment, what population base would you need, maybe 1,500,000 people per Intellovert bar? It's not a happy equation. Only The Lonely Know the Way I Feel All Day Take that classic song by the great Roy Orbison a bit further. It takes one intelligent, rather withdrawn, non-emotive person to know how another such person feels. How these sorts of intellectual hookups could be arranged is a challenge. Maybe the social media could help. However, even when you apply your enormous thinking power to the issue, the answer may still be far beyond you. Martin Levine

It sounds like you are in the beginning stages of an existentialist crisis. http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/existentialism  I know the word "crisis" looks alarming, but it shouldn't. In this case it just means you are examining the point of your own existence. Will I always be alone? Why am I here? Eventually you may even question all existence and come to the seemingly frightening conclusion that we're all born alone and die alone and nothing in life has purpose. "Well, that's horrible! You're depressing, why would you say such things?" Again, I repeat- it is nothing to be alarmed about. Those things are true - to a degree. We are born alone and die alone, but we work to make connections with people who can support us, and that we can support in return. Intelligent or not, there will always be like minded people in the world somewhere and they are never easy to find for anyone. To me, making those connections is why I am here and is a large part of my purpose. No matter how intelligent, wealthy or attractive a person is - it can always be difficult to find true connections so that all of the sharing and giving is not a one way street. Intelligent people may have stricter standards for making friends (in fashion or other), but so might a wealthy person, or a very attractive one. All people fear being used and some are just more cautious than others. An intelligent person can read books on understanding human nature ( Ten Keys to Handling Unreasonable & Difficult People), body language Psychology Today and other psychology tools to assist them in making life long connections with other people.  So we may enter and leave the world with even our best friends not knowing our innermost thoughts, but sometimes that can be a good thing too. I know I find my inner thoughts annoying sometimes, I could only guess my friends would too.

There are already plenty of answers based on personal experience. The consensus is that the answer is “yes”, intelligent people are more likely to be alone, which while not a statistically rigorous result suggests that the empirical answer is also “yes”. Let me give a theoretical argument for why we should expect this to be the case. It is difficult to communicate across an excessive difference in intelligence. Over too large a gap in intelligence, the communications are either too verbose or vague for the more intelligent person, or too condensed and obscure for the less intelligent person. This gap was discussed by Rita Hollingworth and is sometimes known at the Hollingworth gap. It’s possible to bridge this gap, but it takes more effort than is conducive to close personal relationships. This means that people generally need to find other people of comparable intelligence to form personal relationships and avoid being alone. For people of average or near average intelligence, there are plenty of such people and this isn’t difficult. As intelligence departs from the average, the pool of people with whom one could form close personal relationships gets smaller so the chances of being alone gets larger. Thus, intelligent people are more likely to be alone.

Thanks for the A2A. I’ll have to speak for myself. I don’t know that many other highly intelligent people. :) Early in my life, I actually did feel alone. As I was growing up, there were many things I was learning at a rapid rate. Whenever you saw me, I usually had a stack of books in my arms. I read voraciously all the time, and when I wasn’t doing that, I was in my (mostly electronics) “laboratory” I created for myself in the basement, and being a poor boy from a poor family, I did not have much of a budget, so I went scavenging for electronics others would simply toss curb-side. I learned a lot that way, but it isolated me from the other kids. I did play with the other kids from time to time, but I spent much more time reading and experimenting. To the point that my parents thought something “was wrong” with me, and actually took me to a psychologist about it. I recall 6th grade. I knew more science and mathematics than the teacher, which got me into trouble. I would correct her all the time on the science she simply got wrong, and she didn’t like it. I mean, should not the teacher know more than the student? Fortunately, I did not get bullied in school for being so smart. Quite the opposite. I picked up the nick-name of “mad scientist”. Not so bad, I suppose! I’ve only ever had a very few really good friends. I suppose I was into quality, not quantity. I was diffident in those days, and lacked a lot of self-confidence. I mean, I had no one to mentor or guide me. I had to do this on my own. So alone was the default. I lived with it, was ok with it. Not much of a choice, really. When I got to high school, it was the same deal repeated. I had 3 really good friends, 2 Indians and a Jew. We would hang out together after school, and one of my Indian friends was a chess prodigy at the time, perhaps the 2nd or 3rd best chess player in the entire State we were living in in the US. On graduation day, at the end of 12 years of public school, after I was handed my diploma, it hit me hard that this episode in my life was all over, and all my friends were going off to various colleges or doing other things. I felt totally alone in a way far deeper than before. But then, the rest of my life laid in front of me. I didn’t know what I would do. But I would think of something. (BTW, if your recognise the reference, let me know!!!) Spinning massively forward to today, 40 years later, do I feel alone? Yes and no. Actually, it’s not all that important to me anymore. Sometimes I prefer to be alone with my own thoughts. When around others, I always have to find something to spark the conversation, else awkward silence will ensue.

Like other compliments or praise, I find them mostly bull-crap, I  respect criticism and find it more truthful, it allows me room and  direction for improvement.  I have  friends of all types but outside of physical activities there are few I  find interesting or that are on the same level of information,  understanding or emotional control. I find many of them ignorant,  defensive, childish, and often boring or frustrating. I though have a  few friends I find very intellectual that we can converse for hours on  the same level without emotional issues. It I believe is the same thing  in sexual relationships.  I have no issues as long as sex is all we do,  but when we  converse there always seems to be something that  strikes a nerve and it is down hill from there, I hate drama I have little patience or sympathy for those who can not control their emotions. I am most content around  those I find intelligent, an more intelligent is better because they  are more interesting, usually more secure, less emotional and I am learning, I do not know any highly intelligent people who are very active, but I have known many who are extremely skilled at  things and I am both impressed and  drawn to their skills.  I am a visual learner and enjoy learning everything though I need not be the best, I am only satisfied when I know I am equal to. Their are all types of intelligent people, some are more intelligent in social skills than most, some are less, some find a social life less important than others things, there is I believe someone for everyone but if you neither need or want this, it does not matter. Funny though how humans feel  everyone must integrate,  the way of nature has always been for living  things to stay within their own. There are many reasons an intelligent person would like to be alone. They may be an introvert, they may be cocky and think that other people are annoying, they may feel like they don’t fit in, they may be depressed, or they may have social anxiety. Finally, some intelligent people live in areas where intelligence is not accepted. I would say that, just like everyone else, about half of intelligent people are introverted. This is because introverts make up about 50% of the population. So, said intelligent person may be an introvert. Some intelligent people are arrogant and feel that because they are smarter than other people, they don’t have time for them. These people exist in most intelligence bracket and every field. It is not a symptom of being intelligent, simply of having a big ego. People who feel like they don’t fit in, or have social anxiety often avoid people. Some of these people are intelligent. So that might be the reason. People who are depressed often avoid people. Intelligent people can be depressed. This may be the reason an intelligent person want’s to be alone. If an intelligent person lives in an area where they are bullied for being intelligent, they may withdraw from people. If your question implies that intelligent people as a group prefer to be alone, they you are wrong. Intelligence has no connection with wanting to be alone, and people are different. My best friend is very intelligent. She is going to college to finish her junior and senior year of high school and her freshman and sophomore year of college at the same time. She also generally likes to be part of groups. She likes to hang out with friends, and you would think she is an extravert. Not even all introverts prefer to be alone most of the time. My sister is pretty intelligent and she is the most extraverted person I know. She HATES to be alone. In conclusion, intelligent people may want to be alone for the same reason people of average or below average intelligence would want to be alone. Intelligence is not tied to wanting to be alone in any way unless a person is the victim of bullying because of it.

For me, its because my brain thinks about the big picture all the time, and its really all that interests me. So when I socialize, and people wanna discuss simpler things, I have nothing to talk about, or I’ll get all philosophical about whatever topic they bring up, which is just annoying, and I realize that. Things like Nihilism, existentialism, the futility of existence, the future of humanity, space travel etc etc. These aren’t things common people like discussing. Im sure everyone thinks about them from time to time sure, but for me, they colour my whole entire world view, and for others, that’s just extremely depressing and annoying to interact with. Also, I can’t fake my way through common discussions, like who won the latest hockey game, or if I heard about the latest x and y scandal or sexual allegations on the news. So I mostly just keep to myself. It’s entertaining in here anyways. I do however, love going out dancing. This way I get to be among large groups of people, but not have to fully interact with them, just an occasional wave, or hi, how are you. More about just the communal aspect of everyone there, sharing a love for music. Something very enjoyable about that. But yeah, even though I isolate, I am never lonely, and Im thankful for that. Since I see so many other people who are terrified of being alone, that they cling to toxic relationships, and are mostly unhappy. No thanks.

I used to be thought intelligent by some; I don’t know anymore, but . . . Mostly I don’t like having to be “on.” That is, listening to people and responding to what they say when I’m supposed to. It’s a lot of tedious work and usually boring. In those situations I’m usually just waiting for it to be over. I like being around really smart people, really funny people and young beautiful people, but that’s not who I usually get to hang out with. Usually I just want to get back to my NYT crossword puzzle or designing circuits in my head or deciding which of my guitars to drill a new hole in or whatever book I’m reading. I’m never bored when I’m alone; I never have been. I was a completely self-entertaining kid. If I didn’t have anything to work on or anyone to play with, I’d go for a hike or a bike ride. I’m only bored around other people and then only if I’m forced to pay attention to them. One thing I love to do is go to a Starbucks or an IHOP or someplace and just sit and work the puzzles in the newspaper. My favorite place is a restaurant across from the university that is like a huge junior high-school cafeteria. It even smells like one. It is noisy with dishes clanging and kids screaming and hundreds of people talking at once and you even pick your own food up at the counter so you don’t have a waitperson coming around to interrupt you. I love the loud busy atmosphere because, as many people as there are, each jabbering mindlessly about something, I’m not obligated or expected to pay any attention to any of them. I love it. In fact if I did pay undue attention to anyone they’d probably think I was some kind of weirdo pervert person. That’s why I like to be alone, but like I said, if you’re scary smart, wicked funny or movie star beautiful, look me up; I’ll try to come out of my shell.

Yes, i feel very, very lonely right now. When reading this, keep in mind i'm 29 years old. I just went to see a miyazaki movie, and i could not get a single person to come with me. I'm a huge "nerd".  I read about 3-4 books each week,  and i'm constantly feeding my brain with information. When i was 6-7 i re-discovered some mathematical rules because i felt that standard mental calculation was inefficient. At 16-17, i could manage to do  multiple 9 digits operations pure mentally, up to the point my classmates would be unable to keep up with me with a calculator. My true strength is problem solving and pattern recognition, this allowed me to be extremely proficient in computer science. Also, it makes me a decent psychologist without any former training(i have a university psychology student under therapy, if you can believe that.)  I always try to see the best in people, and to enjoy their company. But i have a problem: to me, to use an example from one of the answers, it feels exactly like talking to children. They have often problems that i cannot relate in any way, because either i would not have the problem in the first place, or the solution is so obvious to me, that i pass off as " the know-it-all" guy. I can cover from literature to physics to biology, psychology, Japanese culture, medicine, mechanics, i could(i'm rusty) play guitar to genius level, receiving praises from people that had a formal and complete musical education. Also, English is not my first language, and i learned it all by myself, learning trough reading and listening non translated content. I did all kinds of works: from the tech guy of a store, to play music for a living, carpenter, plumber, stall boy, IT consultant, i even went on tv and posed as a tarot card reader without effort.  EVERYTHING i do feels very, very boring. Like there is no true challenge, only a level of effort of a slightly higher quality that i do not want to put in for something so boring. I do not have any real friends, and i never had a lasting relationship. The last one failed because she felt a sense of inferiority to me, and i assure you she was a very bright and smart girl, surely in the 130/140iq range but she could not take the pressure. Every time i'm forced to talk to people it feels to  me like i have to "decompress" information to make them understand me. like when you need to explain to a child why does it rain in very simple words. My brother-in-law, a very very smart person still finds it difficult to follow me when i start talking at the abstraction level(PhD at La Sapienza,Rome)  Even on a subject he knows very well, his mind can't make the connections fast enough for him to follow, and i have to slow down. I realized soon enough that my thoughts are processed at a speed several times that of the people around me, because i learned how to skip the thought-through-words brain level and think straight with the thought-through-concepts level. That also allows me to completely disengage  meaning and language, gifting me the capacity to understand foreign languages or extremely hard concepts( like, imaging space as quadri-dimensional entity) with minimal effort(though the only language i'm proficient in,beside Italian, is English.)All the stuff above, makes me a very, very, very lonely person. I often questioned if i was raised by my biological parents or not, what i feel is total alienation from "common" people, and at some point in the delusions that came growing up with such a mind, i also asked myself if i was some kind of genetic mutation.  If you ever wanted to ask a member of an endangered species, "how does it feel to be the last of your kind", i think i can answer you;  It's very, very lonely, and it has a sense of doom.

I agree with Andy McNish’s comment in his answer: “high intelligence makes you more comfortable with being alone.” Developing your cognitive capacity helps to build a kind of independence, you have your own psychological resources. My family tends to be introverted, working class autodidacts, who influenced me to look to constant reading. Doing this from a young age meant I built up cognitive capacity, and this was reflected in the tests schools given to children (which are derived from the same source as IQ tests). This building up of cognitive capacity is something that requires work on your part — it doesn’t just come with genes. This is a reason that scores on IQ tests can be affected in various ways — can be changed through kinds of study. In my youth I was also sort of clueless in regard to social skills — relating to others. But the thing is this: Social skills can be learned. Through being a teacher and doing union organizing, I learned how to talk with people, to communicate in their own language, to listen. I also developed my ability to be more empathic — which I was not as a teenager. In recent decades I’d say I’m fine with being alone. My occupation as a writer means I do my own research and do writing as my own activity — fits in with my psychology. But I also really like getting together with friends, and I like my occasional political or other group meetings. It’s just that I can only put up with so much of it.

I don’t know that all intelligent people want to stay by themselves. Personally, I love to read anything and everything and have a thirst for knowledge and have had since I was a child. It’s been my experience that not a lot of people share my interests and perhaps I bore them with my topics of discussion. I will find a subject and read everything I can find in the library as well as online. I stay away from politics, religion, and surgeries. A lot of the people I know want to discuss those three subjects and are so fixed in their opinions that sometimes in my mind’s eye they appear to look like rabid animals. I am past the point in my life where I have to control, nag, attempt to manipulate, or spend time convincing someone to adopt my points of view. I just want to enjoy whatever time I have left on the planet. I hope I leave this world having made a worthwhile contribution and I do that by tutoring grade school children in math and reading at no cost to their parents. Frankly, I get more out of the time spent than the children, but when after a few sessions they start getting 100’s on tests and/or increase several levels it makes me happy that I’ve done something worthwhile. I like people. I just don’t enjoy chatter.

I suspect high intelligence makes you more comfortable with being alone. The curse and gift of high intelligence is that your brain never stops thinking. Intelligent people can be highly social and extroverted. But even those that are are often very comfortable when left alone with just their hyperactive brains for company. They don't get bored spending hours with the ideas spinning around inside their heads. And for many of the more introverted ones, it can be their preference. I lived with a friend who was doing a Physics PhD at the time, called Rob. I went off to work quite often with him sitting on a sofa, staring at a wall. 9 hours later I'd come back and he'd be sitting on the same sofa, staring at the same wall. We were worried that he was depressed in some way, but, no, he was fine. He just liked to spend most of his time on “Planet Rob”.

I love being alone. Sure there are moments of loneliness…but by and large I make it through those moments. I paint, I write, I’m a jazz pianist, I sculpt, I design and build furniture. I once read a lot, but now reading just puts me to sleep. I thoroughly enjoy driving trips and 2 years ago returned to California after I and my dog Bear spent 2 years traveling the western states. Camping, motel-ling and hotel-ling or sleeping under the stars in the bed of my truck. I can count the friends I’ve had through my lifetime, on my fingers and have a few fingers leftover. What few friends there have been were very good friends. There have been many acquaintances…but they were just that. I live with a lady…a companion…thankfully she is gone quite a bit. I miss her for a day or two when she is gone, but ease right into being a loner very quickly. And when she returns I love having her with me…for a short while…then I find myself looking forward to her next trip. She a loner as well, but somewhat more social than I am. We are a good match. We built her a ‘tiny house’ which is parked next to the house (we live in the country) because there are times she wants to ‘escape’ from me and be alone…or at times I’ll use the tiny house to escape from her. All in all it works out well. Answer; yes. alone time is very valuable and I believe required for peace of mind for intelligent as well as creative people.

Most people have a short attention span which is why the media portions out the news in sound bites directed at an 8th grade level audience. There is a general societal-wide attitude that intelligent people should get some respect but the average person responds interactively with intelligent people in a manner that dismisses that person's intellect because they feel discomfited because they resent feeling like they are being schooled by a teacher. Because they feel inferior or envious, people interacting with highly intelligent persons often attempt to categorize that person in a somewhat negative stereotype such as "geek" or the "absent minded professor".  A person of intellect has these experiences frequently in most social circles and because of this chooses to limit such profitless activity.   So, the answer to your question is yes, intelligent people are more likely to be alone as society does not really promote them. The caveat is that when a highly intelligent person finds a suitable mate, they are extremely loyal and generous with that partner and shower their partner with love, attention, and affection, because they appreciate and value that person so highly.

In short, the answer is YES! Most intellectually gifted beings are introverts. Where as they typically draw into themselves more often than not. [Question: Why are geniuses always solitary individuals?] I suppose some of them might be solitary because they think differently from others and it can be difficult to form relationships with people who think differently. But there are geniuses who are not solitary, and there are non-geniuses who are solitary, and I am not aware of any real evidence (just a few examples) that geniuses are more likely to be solitary than others. I think it is most likely that geniuses are solitary for the same reasons (and there are many reasons) that anybody else is solitary. There is a sort of mythology of geniuses as being very different from other people. It is mostly false. Geniuses are mostly just like anybody else. And they usually don’t make a big deal about it, so you don’t know it when you meet one. Some possibilities of where the solitary genius idea might come from: People who make a big deal about being a genius (a rather large percentage of whom are not geniuses by any definition other than inflated self-image) tend to be rather obnoxious people. Nobody wants to be around them.There is a condition called savantism where a person is incredibly good at one thing, but struggles at many other things including interpersonal skills. It is rare, possibly an autism-spectrum disorder, and most geniuses are not savants.Some people feel cheated because others are gifted, and console themselves that geniuses pay a price in other areas. But the universe isn’t fair that way.

Intelligent people need alone time to pick at their brain and have ‘debates’ with themselves, so to speak. They find it hard to think when there’s a lot of outside activity around them. Intelligent people are usually creatively-inclined, so they spend a lot of time alone to work on their craft. Intelligent people are aware of the fact that most people are pathetically ignorant, so they don’t see the value in socializing( Intelligent people like having conversations and aren't intrinsically averse to human interaction, mind you). *Full disclosure: my IQ is around 110–120(High verbal IQ, low spatial IQ). I have a brother who’s IQ is 120–130( High on both types), and most of what I’m writing comes from observing him. I don’t think my Mom’s been evaluated, but she did tell me that she aced the SAT. My writing also reflects my observations of her behavior. To really achieve things, like what most intelligent people are interested in, you need to work in solitude. Einstein was a solo worker, as was Darwin.

You probably meant “the most intelligent people” or “more intelligent people than me”, since there is not such thing as “just intelligent”, because it lacks comparability and assumes perfection, which (perfection) does not exist. Coming back to what you asked and probably wanted to hear, the answer is yes. The more intelligent the person is, the less people there are that could interest them enough so that the person does not seem bored. Imagine, that there is a person who is 1000 years old and this person is the only one of this age alive, other are 100 years old maximum. Now imagine that all those people try to relate to this “millenial” with the same problems / events / questions / stories that this person has already heard multiple / hundreds / thousands of times. For example, a father, fully covered in joy tears, who has just seen birth of his daughter, approaches this person with her, and says “isn’t she wonderful? isn’t the birth of a human the most amazing thing?”, but the 1000 years old person has seen this “crap” hundreds / thousands of times already and this is just completely out to their sphere of interest. Now, you might say that there is no such person who reached even 200 years old. Yes, there is none, if you count “age” by the years of existence, not by the amount of experiences / associations in comparison to the “average person”. But if you count it by the latter, I can reassure you there are people that are ~1000 years old living on this planet right now. All of the above mentioned does not, probably, mean that that particular “oldie” or any other “oldie” is certainly alone, but there is undoubtedly a correlation between intelligence and “thickness of the filter” that people have towards stuff (including alive beings), that might interest them, that they encounter throughout their life. You can interest a child with a colored striped stick, but show it to their father and his face will manifest surprise or bewilderment. You can in the same way appeal to the average person with new features on your phone in the latest OS release, but…

Depends on the type of intelligence you're talking about. There are certainly people with very high IQs whose interests are limited to narrow ranges that people with normal IQs can't understand. Such people by definition then aren't going to want to interact with a lot of people and thus are more likely to be alone. Additionally it's common for intelligent people to be anxious. If you cannot enjoy other people because such interactions fill you with stress, then you'll probably isolate yourself. It's crucial to understand though that the ability to understand someone else's perspective is itself a type of intelligence, and those that can do this are LESS likely to be alone. One might be tempted to classify this as a simplistic "IQ isolates, EQ brings together",  but I think anyone who dismisses themselves as simply being good at the former and not the latter isn't being entirely rational. If intelligence represents on some level the ability to understand things, what does it say if an intelligent person falls apart whenever anything of sufficient complexity gets in their way?

If you often opt to spend your evenings snuggled in bed with a boozy beverage and Netflix, it’s probably a sign you’re an introvert. But while flying solo can reveal a lot about your personality, it might say something about your smarts, too. Yes, it’s true: New research says that introverts could have a higher IQ. Generally speaking, the more often people socialize with friends, the happier they feel. But intelligent people tend to prefer their “me time,” according to a new study by researchers at Singapore Management University and the London School of Economics. Sound familiar? You’ll probably agree with these hidden strengths of introverts , too. To reach these results, the team of psychologists conducted two studies using data from a massive national review of over 15,000 people between the ages of 18 and 28. The first study examined the link between subjects’ scores on an intelligence test, the population density in the area where subjects lived, and how satisfied subjects reported feeling with their lives. Meanwhile, the second evaluated how subjects’ IQ scores compared to their life satisfaction and how often they socialized with friends. Overall, participants who lived in less populated areas reported feeling happier, whereas those with high IQ scores who lived in the same areas felt less satisfied. Most people were also happier the more often they socialized, the results found. But on the flip side, intelligent people reported feeling less satisfied with their lives the more time they spent with friends. These weird habits prove you are smarter than most , too. While these two conclusions seem to contradict each other, the psychologists believe they can be explained by “the savanna theory of happiness.” Here’s the basic rundown: Back when our ancestors were hunter-gatherers, spending time with friends was essential to survive; now, as a result, most of us feel unhappy when we are isolated. But because people with high IQs don’t follow that norm, some scientists believe that intelligent brains are simply more adaptable to what would otherwise be unusual environments, such as being alone or living in crowded communities.

The general consensus is that "smart people" have a high IQ. That could not be more further from the truth. Intelligence is not just a human trait, it's a biological trait. Any thing that lives has intelligence, however basic that may be. Last time I checked, a dolphin would miserably fail an IQ test but could outwit most of the authors here. Probably even myself. Intelligence is not only the ability to apply logic and reason but also show empathy and draw from experience. In short, intelligence is nothing but the ability to adapt. Hence truly, a smart person will never be alone but rather choose when it is necessary to be alone and not. I read some of the responses to this, and a lot of them make sense. I would like to add one more thing however, since I’ve known many gifted and genius level people during my life. I do find that some don’t want to stay by themselves, and that they do mix well. Some top sales people, for example, who interface with prospects in order to close a sale, get excited and really enjoy selling despite being mentally gifted. They love the challenge; they love working with people. One of the most important ingredients of a highly intelligent person is engaging in and enjoying challenges. And while some are satisfied with doing complicated word puzzles, playing chess, or determining how good they are at spacial reasoning, others like the challenge of being triumphed at sports, business, sales, and other vocations enable them to work with other people to solve problems. So to repeat, if there is a single characteristic that defines the highly intelligent individual, it is engaging in challenges, whether physical or mental, that requires them to use their brain.

I think that it is passion for hobby or interest rather than intelligence, that makes you more likely to be alone. This internal world may make it hard for the outside world to understand, or they might just not be interested. I think that it is a common problem artists, intellectuals, philosophers, scientists, economists, etc... deal with: I don't think that it is specific to a certain branch. How to define "intelligence" is always dubious. I'm not sure in how far this is by itself the result of passion, because the state of being a "genius" is in my opinion the result of hard work and creativity, which are driven by passion, and which are not so easily achieved in a short period of time.

Intelligent people, like less intelligent people, vary hugely in how much they like to be alone. Take two really, really intelligent people: John von Neumann and Richard Feynman. Both thrived (in different ways) when they were around people. JVN loved being in somewhat typical social situations: Parties and dinners and so on. Feynman would do work in bars and such. But, of course, some intelligent people do like being alone a lot - and for the same reasons as others: They may be easily overwhelmed by noise, they may simply like solitude, they may have odd personal habits, they may find it difficult to be social. One good example of this is Paul Dirac. He really didn’t like being around anyone. And, while I will not engage in the pernicious habit of diagnosing the dead, one biography of him is titled The World’s Strangest Man. Dirac shared very little of anything with anyone. And some very intelligent people are, to use technical language, nuts. One example of this is Kurt Godel. I am pretty sure he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. And yet other intelligent people only like being around other intelligent people.

People come in all shapes, shades and sizes. You can’t stereotype any one particular group and make one narrow statement about all of them. But the many intelligent people who like to be alone typically like it for different reasons than the less intelligent loners. First of all: intelligent people often chose to be alone because we can. We are not dependant on having a group of loud friends around us at all times to validate our existence, or our social status. We are comfortable spending Some time with just our own thoughts And reflections, rather than needing to act like drunken monkies at all times. I remember noticing this early in school. As we got older, (junior high/high school and perhaps especially after graduation, in the Army) I started to feel I was growing up and above that “drunken monkey-behaviour” but many if my piers wheren’t. Nothing wrong with messing about and having fun. I’m all for suspending rational thought for a while and just “go with it”, but the way I see it that should be the exception, not the rule. I find myself quickly bored by this. I need actual intelectual stimuli to keep myself engaged. If I never get it, I quickly retract and go back to enjoying my own company, pondering over deeper issues, reading forums or chatting with like-minded friends and strangers online. Reason two: unfortunately, our social society (especially with the teenager and Young-adult crowd) is run by “drunken monkies”. The asshole frat-guy type who finds any and all conversations deeper and more meaningfull than “what kind of beer do you like?” “Budweiser” “okay” to be nerdy, tedious and boring. The one who would be rough-housing on the floor 24/7, rather than ever be alone with his thoughts, reflect on deeper issues, or raise his hand in class and answer a difficult question he happends to know the answer to. These people reject Intelligent people and writes them of as just being “nerdy and lacking in social IQ”, and unfortunately, these alpha-male types drag down with them a lot of people who, whilst perhaps not the brightest bulbs in the world, are actually smarter than they show themselves to be. These experiences throughout childhood and Young adulthood are perhaps one of the main reasons why intelligent people develop a habit and a need to be alone Every once in a while. This might then persists into adulthood, Even as their piers grow out of this “drunken monkey” behaviour and become capable of having deeper conversations. Keep in mind this is all from my own perspective. Like I said, everyone is different, and whilst my explenations apply to me and Some people I know, it could be totally off for the rest of the world. Apologies for any spelling/gramatical errors. English is not my first languge, and I’m on a phone with a Norwegian Keyboard and auto-correct.

= A normal distribution (bell-shaped curve) shows intelligence on the x-axis with measures of various intelligence levels (IQ) ranging on the x-axis from a low of (I-don’t-know) on the left to a high of let us say 200 off to the right. For each score on the x-axis, the y-axis shows the percent of a population with that score. IQ may not be intelligence’s best measure, but IQ tests at least test people’s ability in doing that IQ test. Really smart people do well on IQ tests, which does not say sb with 100 IQ is not intelligent. Yet chances are that he cannot keep up with sb. whose IQ is 145. As IQ scores rise fewer and fewer have that score. Sb really intelligent is unlikely to find sb else as smart, esp. in a small town. In a big city of large population (say 12,000,000) there may be only five with IQ 200. How do they find one another? Odds are against their ever meeting. So let us say your IQ is 200. You will unlikely find another 200 even in a huge city. When one is into Art History, Architecture, Music (play piano and violin) Electrical Engineering, advanced Math, Physics, Astronomy, Ancient Greek, Sanskrit, Shakespeare and other English greats, how does one share those interests with others? Chances are small that one does. He or she spends a lot of time alone. My example is extreme, but applies to people whose IQ’s would measure above 125. In 1972, the average (median IQ) at Harvard College was 135. At Harvard graduate schools it was 125. Even those with IQ 125 have trouble finding boyfriends, husbands, girlfriends, and wives not to mention friends of their own sex who share similar interests. Chances are that really smart people will not find an even match which could strain a marriage or a relationship that looked good at first.

I'm no Dr Phil, but I can speak of my personal experiences. I have been a loner since I can remember and prefer to be alone now. I had an injury and was disabled I went into truck driving so I could be alone. After twenty years of this whilst reading and studying everything I could get my hands on (particularly with Christianity but I will study whatever trips my trigger), I was diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder with ‘above average intelligence for my age group’, whatever that means. To other people I am incredibly, awkwardly, odd. I can be quite the conversationalist if I am with someone worthy of conversation. This is incredibly rare because too many are overly emotional, ill-mannered, and hopelessly uniformed. With most people you have the equivalent of a Tweet or less to communicate your point or you're getting interrupted with a likely subject change. I have learned that when people initiate conversation, I just let them talk though most times I can't relate. Honestly, if it helps them to vent, I'm glad. This use to really bother me but I have learned how to be attentive and yet let it roll off my back (I think this is just life for neuro-typical people but learned for an autistic). Then there is the point of saturation. One can learn so much about various things that everything meshes into an understanding that is so enormous it pushes the limits of your sanity. Then you get really weird. You say things and people's eyes glaze over because you have blown their mind, slipped and let them see your insanity, or committed some blunder of social etiquette. So, you withdraw… into yourself, your insane self… Then you get drunk… can't get high because of random drug screening, and all is well

It's possible. But the question seems to be asked as if being alone is a negative. And for some, I suppose that it is. I spent my childhood desperately trying to find alone time. I was a middle kid of 6, and I remember the relief when I finally got my own room. It was a tiny alcove off my two older sisters' room, unheated, so the door was louvered to allow some heat in during the brutal winters. But it was MINE. I could sit on the bed, or on the floor, reading and reading, with the door closed so people knew that I wanted to be ALONE. I'm a mom of four, and was a single mom for over a decade after divorcing my first husband. ALONE was the holy grail.  When you enjoy thinking, learning, reading; those things are best done in quiet places, alone. I suspect that many other very intelligent people feel the same way that I do. I love my family and friends. I cherish the time I spend with them. And I also cherish the time that I can spend doing what I love best: learning and thinking about what I've learned.

No. Truly intelligent people see the worth in many things and understand that someone doesn't need to be good at something like non verbal reasoning to be enjoyable to spend time with. Intelligence is also not the same as wisdom, it's not the same as living a good life, it's not the same as having a sense of humour and it certainly isn't the same as achieving anything. It might be difficult to find people who can challenge you effectively or keep up with you in one or two ways, but how many of your conversations really involve in depth, highly conceptual discussions? How many of those do you even want to have on a daily basis? People use intelligence as an excuse for being alone, when the reason is usually just poor social skills. Humans are social animals, there's a reason solitary confinement is a very effective punishment. Some enjoy alone time more than others, but the reality is we all like to have company, we evolved like that over millions of years. Intelligence doesn't really change people's desire to be together. Look at how much people love spending time with their pets!

Smart people are more likely to be alone for several reasons. First, being smart usually includes intellectual curiosity that may require some amount of independent study, which, to a really smart person, is fun. Smart people may have a hard time finding peers, not in any moral sense, but a social one. Smart people have interests that bore the hell out of a non-smart person, and they must pursue these interests alone or with one or two partners. Smart people have a strong sense of metacognition. They are involved in thinking in a way others may not be, making them seem detached and even eccentric because they manage a busy internal agenda. And finally, in my experience, really smart people also have a high degree of emotional and social intelligence. They can navigate the complex principles of interconnectedness, sustainability, progressivism, and moral conduct. They possess an independent, internal moral compass that makes irrelevant the efforts of church or state to control their behaviour. They are consequently more likely to take unpopular positions on issues, which may make them to appear hard to know when they become too earnest.

Uninterrupted thinking is its own reward.Before I was forced into finding out I enjoyed high school sports, before I decided that I enjoyed being “it” and saving lives, before I met my wife, had children, and followed a few dreams,… I was quite content to research for researches sake, do my own little experiments based on questions the research raised, and sit and ponder, all without any strong need to be around others. I still did those things, but it became rare that I could have the coherence of my own thoughts without interruption. I won’t claim to be “very intelligent”, but I will stick to my belief that solitude and its freedom to  focus and center ones thought is something you have to have to appreciate.

It's hard to tell, but one of the most significant wounds to the question is the definition of what a "smart" person is. We don't even have a universal definition of intelligence - while they generally cover the same vague notions, you can yourself see the difference between them. Is a smart person inherently more smart than others, or is based on their circumstantial intelligence? There's also the problem of artifacts. Would being social make the person less likely to be noticed as being smart? Or, if being smart and sociability don't contradict each other, your question is better phrased as "Are [not smart] people more likely to be social?". Are they, really? Finally, a third hurdle to your question: if someone's alone, how do you find them? If they're not social, how do they become recognised for the survey? What, exactly, do you mean by "alone"?

Hi Swharz Sardlee, I’m not so sure about always, but perhaps some intelligent people do isolate themselves more than, let’s say, the “layman”. For example, there are some “laymen” who are both kind and friendly, yet others are vitriolic. All people prefer to socialize with those they have something in common with — people they can talk to and understand. “Smarter people” are a very small percent of the population. The cut-off for joining Mensa, the high-IQ society with the lowest requirements, is being in the top two percent. That’s one person out of fifty. Someone “did the math” to figure out what the practical communication range is, in terms of IQ, when discussing anything but superficial “Hi, how’s the weather? Did you watch the game last night?” stuff, and it’s about 30 IQ points. Someone with an IQ of 130 can communicate well with almost everyone; both an average 100 and a high-genius 160 are within their range. On the other hand, someone with an IQ of 160 can talk to the 130s and above… but that’s only two percent of all people. It’s not that highly intelligent people are all extreme introverts (although some introverts want you to think so, because then they may be able to convince you that smart = introvert = smart), but that there are fewer people for us to choose from when looking for someone to socialize with in any deep and meaningful way. We don’t want to make average people feel bad when they can’t keep up (fun fact: there’s a strong correlation between intelligence and compassion), so what choice do we have but to socialize primarily with other highly intelligent people?

Here it comes down to the definition of intelligence that you have: If you're talking about “rational intelligence”, then you are referring to the left hemisphere of the brain. In our western society this is often still seen as the standard for measuring ‘intelligence'.Then there is the “emotional intelligence”, this one lays in the right side of our brains and is the main part involved in social interactions.Generally every human being tends to have one side of the brain more evolved than the other. It's therefore sometimes the case that people we call “intelligent”, those who have a highly stimulated left side, end up having a less developed right side of the brain, therefore having a harder time socializing. As a result of which they enjoy spending more time on their own. Of course this is an oversimplification, there are many contradictions to this model and many cases confirm that it's not always 100% true. But the fact remains that intelligence is much more than our hability to solve scientific problems and we as a society must make an effort to value and encourage every other aspect of our nature that makes us ‘intelligent’ human beings.

My work required social interaction with a group of scientists, engineers and often their spouses. We had to meet in different countries, so dinner invitations to a host delegate’s home, or to a restaurant, gathering for cocktails, touring locally together, was the norm. I was rarely alone. Not only did I enjoy the job, I enjoyed the people. We were like an extended family. When I left this work and no longer needed to travel, it was if a switch flipped. For years I had no desire to even leave the house, though eventually my wanderlust returned a bit. Now my husband jokes I can be found in one of two places: in the house or in a foreign country. If I can’t be alone, after a while I feel so unsettled I’ll check into a hotel, if necessary, and hang a do not disturb sign on the door. I love people and enjoy being around them, but not non-stop. Given enough time and space I’ll recharge, ready for the world again. Am I an introvert or an extrovert? Not sure, but like clockwork, my MBTI changed when I stopped working from ENTJ to, you guessed it, INTJ. If I don’t have to be extroverted I’m not. When I have to be, I open to the experience and enjoy almost anyone I’m around. I could be happily alone for weeks, months—reading, writing, learning something new. For years? Maybe not. I must be a hybrid.

There are other variables at play sometimes. I know someone who is “aphantasia”; “face blind”, “color blind” and “tone deaf”. He also is someone who has almost no recollection of his life. No memories. He is simply not able to assemble the data necessary to accommodate past associations, past experiences, past responsibilities (such as remembering names, recalling previous details about the other person and therefore seeming to be uncaring about what the other person may have confided previously). It is torture for this person to “associate”… he very much prefers to observe. His powers of observation and deduction are off the charts. He sees things most others miss. He knows what’s going to happen before anyone else. He must feel like he is the most intelligent person in the room. All this because (I suspect) he cannot facilitate and/or make room for other “data”. He is therefore left free to simply observe, consider and deduce… while the rest of the people are busy accommodating social reciprocity.

All human beings have innate intelligence, which could also be described as the “common sense” that we share equally, but which is sometimes buried by other factors, such as by religion or the philosophies of men. Some of us like to be alone, because we enjoy being around ourselves. We like ourselves. We love ourselves. We also love our neighbors, including our enemies, as ourselves. However, if other human beings are not kind to us, or think too highly of themselves, we withdraw from them and choose to be alone, rather than to allow them to interfere with our peace and our patience. Some of us also like to “ponder”. We wonder who we are and why we exist. We like to reflect upon these things. Some of us believe that the “kingdom of God,” a metophor for the real truth, is found within—by reflecting on our own soul and remembering, ever so faintly, what life was like before mortality.

response.answer_text: I think it’s because intelligent people are more analytical and these skills are usually best developed when alone. However, I did have friends in college who learned better by teaching as they learned with others around. Another thing is that being part of a group tends to promote conformity and conflict/drama. Not all conformity is bad and drama is inevitable in building relationships. With that said, think about the “negative” conforming trends in college. Partying, drugs, immature relationships, etc. I am not saying all these things are bad but they tend to be more of a distraction for someone achieving their goals. By either choosing to spend time alone or spending time with a select few, one can focus on what they can control and their goals, i.e. good grades and career.

It is not to say that all clever people enjoy their solidarity, but I reckon that these reasons apply yo a lot of intelligent people based on my several experience of talking to smart people.

response.answer_text: I don't see any specific correlation between the two, given I see few signs of “brilliance” in loners and hermits. Intelligence more often inspires invention and innovation and requires cooperation with others to develop and express it. There are enough intelligent extroverts and socially driven people and not exceptionally intelligent introverts and loners, to provide exceptions to such a narrow viewpoint, that I find no reason to think intelligence is a major factor in wanting to be alone.

People with a high IQ are more likely to get married than people with a low IQ - 29% more likely, according to one study: 15 Signs You'll Get Married  However, people with a high IQ are also more likely to delay getting married to pursue advanced degrees and other life goals. That depends. If you mean physically alone, the answer is definitely yes, not necessary due to external constraints, but because smart people tend to enjoy solitude. They have multiple mental and sensory processes going on and don't bore themselves to death. The opposite is also true: dumb people, as a rule, loathe being alone.Conversely, if you mean the feeling of being alone, the answer is definitely no, for the exact same reasons.
