Intelligent people are intelligent because they are capable of achieving a desired result. Succeeding academically, solving problems, and even obtaining social standing are examples.  An intelligent person that takes on pursuits that result in them being alone means that it is a choice for that person to be alone.  But how intelligent can a person be if they don't want to be alone, yet can't achieve that desired result?

Not all highly intelligent people prefer to stay alone but for the sake of the question I'll give you a couple of reasons why some do: 1.) some of them don't want to be alone but are simply too anxious to approach other people, hence their loneliness. (many smart people have to deal with a variety of anxieties, not all but a good amount of them) 2.) while others prefer to be alone simply because they're introverted. Those people literally get exhausted from being around other people and talking to them. If they attend social events they'll need some alone-time afterwards in order to recharge. 3.) in some rare cases extreme childhood bullying has scarred an individual to the point where:  a) the individual is actively avoiding other people, or  b) becomes a bully himself and people avoid him, because he's unpleasant to be around *cough* Sheldon *cough*

As a group, no.  Some smart people prefer isolation, or extreme introversion, or distanced misanthropy, but barely at different rates than any other categories of intelligence. But, if I am not reading too far into your implications, I think it is safe to say that many, many smart people would not rather be dumb and more socially lubricious or successful than they currently are. Falling outside the average bounds of various social and cultural structures can make socializing more difficult, or less, more profitable, or less.  The "tortured, socially awkward nerd" archetype is more valuable as an expression of cultural values, perceptions, and fears than as an accurate representation of a class of individual---though the stereotype is definitely self-admitted by some people who feel it works for them.

Because we don't relate well to “average” people. Our thoughts and concerns are more complex. Our thinking much deeper. I used to be really good at “small talk" but I realized how draining it was to have to have this “alternate persona" when working in customer service. I'm much happier reading articles about the latest space endeavors, reading about medicine/philosophy/theology/sociology, watching documentaries. I would rather have a discussion about the implications of string theory on how we perceive our own subjective reality than say the weather. So it's really a desire for a more meaningful deeper existence and connections that offer that; which means escaping the vapid, shallow, self indulgent, greedy, simplistic crust of society.

Yes, and no. The reward curve is different for people with high IQs. If you are normal, most people like the same things as you do, they can help you mutually with your homework, and you can relate to their lives and bond over mutual experiences. If you are not normal, that bonding is not going to happen and you have little in common with your age-group peers. They cannot help you with your homework, but still want you to help them with theirs. While this changes when you become an adult, those childhood habits have fossilized into adult behaviors. Most people, regardless of IQ tend to keep behaviors they learned as a child even if they no longer benefit them or are even self-destructive.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Jimmie Perry III

response.answer_text: Let’s imagine that smartness is like computer processing power. Have you ever noticed someone who just blurts out what they are thinking? Their processor runs at about the speed of human language. Now imagine if you had a really fast processor. One that runs much faster than human language. In fact, you have to make yourself slow down, pare away some peripheral concepts, etc. just to express your thoughts. That’s what it’s like for smart people. Which would be more fun: Playing around with your ‘fast’ multi-processor computer running multiple apps and graphics and such, or flipping the switch and using MS-DOS? DOS does work OK for conversations, and there are smart people who genuinely enjoy The Human Tragicomedy. Sometimes smart people prefer to just put on the headphones and heat up their processors, too.

Speaking for myself, yes. I prefer the company of bright people, but they can be hard to find. Going to church allows me quality time while with day-to-day folks I have to be polite and guarded. Thank God for Quora and the public Library!

As with all why-do-intelligent-people questions, if you remove the word “intelligent,” the question is exactly the same. Why are people so insistent that intelligence makes a person no longer human? Why does human nature no longer apply to us? Why are we no longer individuals, but a mass of beings who are all the same? It’s a little like assuming all tall people not only want to play basketball, but are very good at it. People are people, regardless of their height, intellect (or lack of), or any other genetic factor over which they have no control. I wish I could think of some way to communicate this to the public at large.

Thanks Natalie for A2A. Yes. General consensus is in that direction. Reasons are well explained. There are a number of very good answers. Intelligence and smartness has been discussed and correlated. Remaining lonely however have very wide connotations. They may be alone on purpose. They are better time managers. They want to optimize the usefulness of their time. They want to shield themselves from time and energy wasting activities. Solitude is needed when deep thinking is to be done. INTELLIGENT PEOPLE USUALLY DESCEND DEEPER IN THINKING WELL. They do not want others to be around when they are busy doing that. They are within a company only when it is UNAVOIDABLE. Thanks for reading my answer.

A common theme in superhero movies is that “people fear what they don’t understand”. Giftedness in general can be a very controversial topic, due in part to the fact that many people don’t like to think that someone else is naturally better than them at something. But it’s not just about skills or talent. It’s about the way we think. Giftedness is part of us, so it might be hard to form connections with certain people. So, in summation, the loneliness comes from a lack of connection (sometimes even if you have “friends”), and the misunderstanding comes from— society? Sorry, that seemed to fall flat. I don’t know exactly why gifted people are misunderstood. Something about superstition or lack of modern science back then, or materialistic and shallow modern culture…

Had your question been : Are smarter people more likely to be alone? I would have said Yes. But lonely? Never Herein lies the smartness. To be alone and yet not be lonely. A smart person knows how to handle life even when alone, They won’t ever feel lonely. And yes, a smarter person will be alone inasmuch as there are not many smart people out there, so they will have a dearth of company.

To be honest with you, intelligence does come at quite a cost; the common problem with it is that it requires an audience and the more one fails doing that successfully, the more is he/she vulnerable to loneliness. So, you know, it's best to remain discreet and not be too showy-offy about IQ and all such related things. Discretion is the reason why most intelligent people are awesome comedians-it's a nice cover!

Well I’m going to answer this from my perspective, as being an intelligent person who prefers his own company to others qualifies me for providing an answer to this question. I’ll say now that these are my reasons for liking to be alone, I can guarantee you that others will have differing reasons to myself. Without further delay, here be my reasons: Others aren’t capable of followering my thought track, so I generally lose people within a sentence or two.Others don’t know what I’m talking about. There are exceptions to this, like some of my smarter friends.Humans are cruel abusive creatures that attack the things they don’t understant, i.e. MeI am capable of holding a mental debate with myself for up to an hour on the most trivial of things. Don’t get me started on complex subjects.I don’t like the vast majority of people. Sorry it’s nothing personal, atleast with most people.This one is kind of odd, but people call me Sheldon, as in Sheldon Cooper, so I am half inclined to behave like him. I’m quite good at it.Edit: A Andy Smith pointed out to me something about the Sheldon Cooper nickname. So in light of what he said, it is one of my many nicknames and they aren’t to be heeded as any real effect towards my preference of my own company, as I gained the nicknames only in the last year or two. I also have the nicknames of Siri, Dictionary and Google, just to give some perspective.

Somewhat of a cliche, are all quiet or alone people intelligent?, as in a high IQ?…..no, fact…people with an average IQ are just as likely to be alone, all people who don’t like the company of others are they showing or expressing a greater degree of intelligence over those who are gregarious…..not likely.

They never have someone on the same intellectual level as them, never having someone to challenge them intellectually. They most likely won't engage themselves in gossip and meaningless conversation like what movie is coming out. Smart people liked to be challenged, pushed to be greater. Not stuck in the same spot doing thing they find boring or pointless

The idea that the intelligent are loners (and/or socially awkward) is an unfounded stereotype. Just as any other group, intelligent people vary widely in their levels of social comfort. Many intelligent people are gregarious and love to socialize. So the premise of the question is flawed. *Edit* It is not my responsibility to Google things for anyone. Have a great day.

That's not entirely true. Truly intelligent people learn with others, not only by themselves. They just need some time alone to think. That BS of wanting to be alone all the time is just people with issues. This question popped up to me due to a stupid algorithm, and quickly got me disappointed with the answers. Egocentric answers doesn't mean real inteligence, just plain old narcissistic personality. But what do i know?!

While the question overstates things quite a bit, there is some truth to the question. Highly intelligent people on average enjoy thinking time. They are less likely to get restless sitting at home with their thoughts. I don’t remember where I read about this, but maybe someone familiar with related studies can add a comment. Always keep in mind that people are individuals and highly intelligent people are not homogeneous. Just because the correlation in the question may exist does not mean that all highly intelligent people are like that.

May be you mean “solitudinous”… Solitudinous is the state of being alone , but mainly as a self-choice. In this state, one actually is not feeling the cold loneliness but the joy of inner world. Most of the intelligent people prefer being solitude, but that does not mean that they are disconnected from people. Of course intelligent people may be alone (socially disconnected), but also the mediocre people may encounter the same.

Because often as not their interactions with other people have been met with bafflement from an early age so they realise quite quickly that other people think they’re weird and so don’t bother to hang out with them. I was never happier than when I was at university with plenty of other intelligent people to hang out with and discuss ideas. On leaving I realised that in the normal world there is a paucity of such people. I am quite naturally extrovert myself and I do consider myself to be fairly intelligent and well read. The best way to interact with people of average intelligence I have found is to simply amuse yourself in playful antics, getting them to believe things that aren’t true or just messing with them a little. I don’t do this maliciously, although of course there are many who do. It saves getting too bored. Of course sadly a lot of intelligent people numb the pain of hanging out with the masses by using drugs to dumb themselves down.

Not always the case ! :) Am pretty smart (in all areas) and I can make friends within seconds ! It’s another matter that I do not enjoy the company of every Tom, Dick and Harry and like to spend time with only those friends who share everything with Me (Read: do not withhold anything from Me) and with whom I can have a blast of a time ! May be the xtreme introverted people are lonely ! :)

I like to be alone but I am also outgoing, I forgot the term I found for it because I fel introverted but I am very social. Anyways, I love hanging out with friends, but too much time with others and I get a little bored with the average conversation. It’s not arrogant, I just find no pleasure in talking about DIY projects or guns or a ton of other subjects. I’d rather gain more knowledge and by hanging out with others with too much leisure, I lose that time and stimulation that I need in my life

The very question is based on wrong presumptions. Not all smart persons prefer to be alone. There are smart and extroverted personalities and also smart and introverted personalities. 'Smart' does not necessarily mean very intelligent. It may be true that very intelligent/ brainy people tend to be introverts. There are plenty of "smart" persons in politics, business management and public administration who are extroverts, people-oriented and jovial.

For many reasons: 1. I had more workload than my peers so my working hours is hectic. I don’t have time to socialise. 2. Being alone and do things alone give me energy. People can be a ‘noise’ sometimes. Plus I pick up other people vibe/energy. The negative ones will drained mine later. Seriously, it does happens. I try to avoid going out a lot with these people. 3. I don’t do office gossip. I ended up nodding (out of to conform social norms than being agree) than fully participating in the conversation. 4. I don’t make small talk at workplace or with close friends. I only do, at the till or just to break the ice with strangers while travelling. 5. I can make people bored easily with heavy deep topics. I hate one side conversation. 6. To avoid being label as snotty smart cookie, I tend to keep to minimal talk. People don’t like to feel inferior or to be told wrong when sometime they are obviously showing basic ignorance. I have passed the age of being people pleaser. Now I stick to my gun. If people think I’m a loner, snob, sound high or mighty, that’s their problems. I find my life amusing. I intend to keep it that way. Those who stay are the keeper. I cherished them at heart. Helps a lot in distinguishing real friends or just a passerby.

Depends. If the intelligent person is a grouch smart as, proving everyone wrong or just somebody who would rather work alone then yes, they would typically be a lonely person. On the other hand, the intelligent friendly people would normally be one of the popular folks and become widely known as that cool guy/girl.

I think they can’t stand having small talk with other people who are so arrogant and always talks about silly things. And actually, it’s none of our business if they are like that. Maybe it’s more weird that some people always like to be surrounded with people even if they are with the wrong company. Or maybe, they are too focused on discovering new things, gauging their capabilities or maybe they are just too lazy. I heard from someone that intelligent people are quite lazy and are introverts.

I think they don’t intend to be isolated. From my experience, I think it’s because “intelligent people” tend to be interested in fields or topics most people aren’t. They’ve become so used to not being understood by the commoners, they just stop bothering that much anymore around people.

There are two kind of people that we use to call ‘intelligent’ but they are different. The real inteligente person is the one that achieved the perfect balance among mind, feelings and will. He/she is a normal social persona, that is pleased being in company and being alone. The other type is the ‘intellectualoide’ —with form of intellectual—. Usually they are persons without good social skills that ‘hide’ themselves in the mind, in the intellectual. They are lone persons that become intellectual-oide!

No, it is not true. I love to socialize. I like to speak with new people and learn new things. All people know things of value and if one gives them the opportunity to talk about their interests one is bound to learn new things. I often follow up with topics that I was introduced to by someone that I just met.

Are you saying that you think there is a greater tendency to socially isolate amongst especially intelligent people than in not-so-intelligent ones, or that the reasons are different for the two groups? I doubt either is true. There are a variety of reasons people prefer to socially isolate. Even if you take an obvious assumption: that smart people like to think a lot, which requires time alone to read, think, or create, you can boil it down to something similar to a dumb person who likes to spend time reading (maybe romance novels) and creating something of their own (maybe they’re a good gardener).

Statistically I doubt it, except at the extreme. If you’re even a tiny bit smart, an infinite range of puzzles and ideas present themselves. Hard to drag others into something they’re likely to find pointless or boring. I don’t want to be alone for its own sake, but relationships are hard work especially if your mind is elsewhere.

Multiple reasons 1st being that not everyone one wants to talk about complex topics. 2nd is you tend to get far better ideas when by yourself, this is partly due to intuition, but not that esoteric bull shit everyone keeps talking about. 3rd. Wise people rather stay silent because you learn far more about everything, especially how people really feel or think. 4th because people are so entitled to their opinions they refuse that it's anything other then a fact. Opinion cant be fact.

I'm guessing that a person who likes peace and quiet to think their own thoughts and to do the things that are meaningful to them, without being constantly interrupted by inane, irritating comments, would welcome the option of living alone. And yes, from what I’ve seen, intelligent people tend to fit this description.

Not all intelligent people tend to be alone, just like not all average people tend to be social. It is not intelligence that determines this factor, but socialization and being intro-extrovert. Not all intelligent people are socially awkward. Maybe this is more a trait of genius people, but still. Social and emotional intelligence is also intelligence and there are people that are highly intelligent in other fields but stupid in those two.

They don’t. In fact, truly intelligent people are usually adept communicators as well as possessing an over-the-top analytical ability. They excel in life socially as well as intellectually. Also, spending more time socializing with friends is actually an indicator of higher intelligence. Most intelligent people have both a strong social intelligence as well as analytical mastery. Look at Dr. Katherine Bouman, for instance.

Smart people are more likely to be alone for several reasons. First, being smart usually includes intellectual curiosity that may require some amount of independent study, which, to a really smart person, is fun. Smart people may have a hard time finding peers, not in any moral sense, but a social one. Smart people have interests that bore the hell out of a non-smart person, and they must pursue these interests alone or with one or two partners. Smart people have a strong sense of metacognition. They are involved in thinking in a way others may not be, making them seem detached and even eccentric because they manage a busy internal agenda. And finally, in my experience, really smart people also have a high degree of emotional and social intelligence. They can navigate the complex principles of interconnectedness, sustainability, progressivism, and moral conduct. They possess an independent, internal moral compass that makes irrelevant the efforts of church or state to control their behaviour. They are consequently more likely to take unpopular positions on issues, which may make them to appear hard to know when they become too earnest.

Not completely. Because there are still plenty of people of “normal” intelligences to be around. Thankfully. And, really, those “other people” aren’t all bad.  I want to be alone—with my nice friends. The ones I can talk to.  Source: [1] Footnotes[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tojjWQvlPN8

Those who are introverted (prefer spending time alone) and intuitive are more likely to be intelligent. Also, as intelligence is often seen unfavorably, smart people can find themselves without friends until they meet others who are like-minded.

They don’t. Intelligent people come in a range of sociability, from hermit to social whirlwind. Those who bury themselves in their work maybe make for more interesting human-interest stories, so you read about them more often.

Truthfully, it hurts to listen to some people praddle on about things they have no concept of. It gives others headaches. Being around others just clutters the mind with whatever whim someone else happens to be chatting about. There is value in balance and being a good friend but when it comes to surviving the feeling if insanity closing in because two guys on the bus next to you are arguing over which outfit Kaitlyn Jenner looked better in last week, it's time to pull the plug and enjoy some peace.

Desire to be alone is not a specific facet of intelligence, nor is it a facet of lack of intelligence. Rather, it is more indicative of personality: introvert vs extrovert. By definition, an introvert energizes when alone and and extrovert energizes when around others. It is possible to be an extrovert with extraordinary intelligence and an introvert with a very low IQ.

Quite often yes. The main reason for this is that it is difficult to find someone who is your intellectual equal. It is no fun being intellectually superior all the time in a long term relationship. It should be a meeting of minds, an exchange of ideas, it will all lead to happiness. I joined MENSA when I was in the UK. That was a big help in meeting people of a similar intelligence.

It's not so much that intelligent people like to be alone, but instead they prefer conversations with substance to small talk. Personally, I avoid large parties because the environment makes it difficult to have a deep conversation and I find speaking with people on a shallow level about insignificant things to be quite unfulfilling and even frustrating at times. Ideally, I prefer groups of 3-5 people. I, as do most intelligent people I know, prefer listening over speaking. 3–5 people allows for the conversation to be slightly more weighted towards listening, while also providing the opportunity for me to speak up if I have a valuable piece of insight to share.

They are very occupied reflecting and with their passions - in my case nonstop philosophical thinking 24/76 and wriitng my books from 4am or often 2am till 10 pm (more than 90 books and 2500 articles and much else Ulrich de Balbian - Academia.edu ), more than 90 videos of my visual art see You Tube an example - the painting is a tree in the fog in my one backyard, my one studio of 4 in different countries. I express and live through and for these disciplines, they allow me total inner peace and to be deliriously happy all theime, wehile contact with most people are negative, pointless, irrelevant. BUT I play with my loving dogs all the time as they are 100 sincere like myself.

An answer I wrote before applies to your question as well. I have re posted it for you. Their thinking process is fine tuned given that they don’t have the distractions of social interaction . They have time to think without being disturbed. Sometimes it is because of their preoccupation in intellectual pursuits that they tend to be introverts.

I relate to and understand what you are saying 100%. I have an iq of 140 and have always needed mental stimulation. I have had this problem my whole life (I am now 56). Even my family don’t get me and I can count on 1 hand the number of friends I’ve had in my life who had similar thinking. Its lonely being a deep, analytical thinker in a world of shallowness.

They don’t. There is no connection between introversion and intelligence. In general I find that having a high IQ on quora is similar to having big breasts on Instagram: everybody wants to flaunt their’s. I would hazard to guess that the question was written by an introvert who fancies himself intelligent and wants to share this information. My suggestion: get over yourself.

Being smart from this underperforming brain delivers knowledge that sounds smart and repeated we like to sound smart, but attracts opposition these SMART PEOPLE do not want to hear causing them to rethink being smart overwhelmingly confounding as cross considerations never connect to intermingle bringing bigger understanding… makes them nervous. Do this: Read Warren Lipson’s answers to people troubled by duality - guiding a trigger ending duality by shifting feeling in the lead expanding to bring more considerations intermingling sides of a coin. Read warren’s site imagining the questions are your questions and guided - you get the fix training your mind to begin to do this on its own, automatically for you.

If you are highly intelligent, you wont have this idea of feeling alone. You just need to be more understanding of people around you which makes you a more attractive personality and thus helping you to reach a higher state of mindfulness and see life in a different perspective rather than looking for security in others.

Subconsciously, I think it's because “we” like order. And humanity, humans, creatures, in its natural state are chaotic and unpredictable. We would rather design something that prevents chaos or design backups in case chaos takes place. Even in the arts, we have a good understanding of the vast spectrum of human emotions that any of the most level-headed mind and the most psychotic, deranged mind can conceive. So human behaviors become predictable and you have already been able to conceive all the multitude of reaction one can take in order to achieve the desired state afterwards. It's boring, really. But productive when it comes to writing movies, stories and screenplays. And thus why we need solitude to have enough brain space to imagine all possible scenarios instead of being caught up with only the mere one single scenario available in front of us. Which is probably why direct human interaction is so boring, you only have access to one possible scenario (that is the only one you're having with one person at a time). When in your head, there are many more exciting possible scenarios and dialogues to explore.

I'd say no. Not that they're more likely to be with people-- just "no". If you are smart (assuming there is such a thing), you would be more likely to figure out how to make friends and meet people of the opposite sex, or you could at least seek enough advice until you learned how. Intelligence gives you more capabilities and options in life, not less.

I’m fairly smart, I wouldn’t really say I was genius or anything, but I’m mostly alone due to the fact that not many can really comprehend some of the things I say and it get’s frustrating trying to simplify things. . . I honestly get tired of trying to explain and simplify, that and the fact I’m just not a people person. . . People scare the crap out of me

Don't have much in common One might be nuts over the latest Kardashians gossip. The other would rather talk about Charmed Particles. Hard to find a common ground in that. And no. They don't always want to be alone. It just gets harder to find like minds. Spirits, when the bar starts at +130.
Because there is so much to observe, discover, learn, analyze, and think about…before sharing your thoughts with the rest of the world :~)

Most people need quiet on order to think. You can't concentrate while people are talking to you. Solitude allows you to control your environment. People don't interrupt or distract you. You can stay in “the zone" where you can focus and get a lot done.

Of course not. Intelligence and wanting to be alone have absolutely nothing to do with each other. There is simply no connection. If you want to be alone or not depends on what kind of person you are, if you are introvert or extrovert, if you are socially gifted, what kind of experiences you’ve had in life etc. Intelligence does not affect that.

I think Smart people enjoy a small friend circle. They do not believe in having too many friends. They believe in quality and not in quantiy. Smart people know the fact that friends are temporary and change with times . So the only friend they will have forever is none other than themselves. They are realistic people and know how to select their friends. They also value the gift of friendship as they are wise people and do not disappoint their close friends.

I don't believe intelligence affects whether or not you prefer social interaction or isolation. I have meant more unintelligent people who prefer to be alone than the opposite as intelligent people naturally communicate with people better than most in most circumstances. And if there was a correlation I believe it would be a weak one.

Why do some intelligent people like to be alone? I am an introvert, and being around a lot of people is very uncomfortable. The other problem that I have is that I am rather socially inept, I like to tell people that I have all the social skills of a rock! This leaves me feeling like I am on the outside looking in quite frequently. My psychologist has also said, and rightly, that I don’t have much patience with people of average intelligence. My brain works so fast and makes leaps of logic that most people can’t follow, and I get tired of having to go back and explain myself in what I consider “baby talk”. I have found that there are two types of people, there are the ignorant and the stupid. Ignorant people don’t know and what to learn. These type of people will ask intelligent questions and indicate that they truly want to understand, in which case, I have infinite patience in showing them what I mean if they have the slightest aptitude for the subject. Stupid people don’t know and could care less, these people I have no patience for. I find if I just stay by myself, I get into less trouble, and there are less misunderstandings.

Well, its quite possible that our bouts of introspective contemplation might hone our instincts by helping us to insightfully perceive certain sets of distinctions that might have otherwise got overlooked. So the point is more about establishing a sense of well defined balance/equanimity and then other aspects will tend to follow en route…….
Interesting question... anyone on the autism spectrum will likely prefer solitude, as will committed introverts. Intellectual pursuits are often solitary, as well, so I will say yes.

People smart emotionally and socially are meant to have strong networks and thrive in society. Those stupid in those areas, regardless of their intelligence in any other area, are meant to be alone. There is no reason, except pride, for a smart person to be emotionally or socially stupid.

In my case… In my case, I tend to be alone because people simply do not connect with me on any level intellectually. I literally have to dumb down my conversations, my jokes, my vocab… so people understand me. I figure it is better to be alone than waste time with others who would break me down over time, than build me up. That’s just me though.

As is sometimes said here on Quora, before you ask why you should ask if. The question is a statement that is false. Richard Feynman was a true genius. He was sociable and interacted in many ways with others. He was found of playing pranks and was well know for his ability to open other peoples combinations locks. He played the bongos at parties. He was well liked by many individuals. One example suffices to do away with the false premise of this question.

ARE super intelligent people more likely to be miserable?  I've never seen any study showing that they are. Stephen Hawking seems to be not very miserable (especially considering his physical condition).  Susskind?  Neil deGrasse Tyson? Now look at winos who have no homes.  Super intelligent?  No.  Miserable?  Usually.

Because the more you think about it the dumber the average person is. Think of any person you know and you can immediately point out their flaws without really understanding them. Why would you want to be with someone who you don't agree with because they have dumb ideas (a good example being racists)

1 - They don’t. Or more, some do and some don’t. Not all ‘intelligent people’ act and behave in exactly the same way. 2- This is just another rubbish question so all the ‘intelligent’ people on Quora can explain why they, as such an intelligent person, are alone all the time.

“Conversation enriches understanding but solitude is the school of genius.” Edward Gibbon Read a book once and it said one of the biggest wastes of time is meetings. Meeting people whether it is friends or when at work. If you want to get things done, you have to do it yourself.

Most definitely. The more highly intelligent one is, the more likely the lonely, misunderstood and shunned. Thus leaving only one alternative. To live alone. So does one fight against the logic of the situation?

If they are lonely, they are not as intelligent as they’d like to think they are. A truly intelligent person can ‘switch’ the way they act around different people and can get others to do things for them. They are likeable because they know how likeable people act; their mannerisms. Good news is, if you feel lonely, you are a lot more social than you think. You just haven’t met the right people; people who can stimulate you.

It's not every time because everyone is near everything but far away from himself . So when they are alone they are one step more closer to their self then after meditating , introspection they are more closer to their heart & soul . When they are in crowd they look like different from others that's why you call them smart
Many because of some form of loneliness and isolation. Any minority group is likely to suffer from being different from the masses.

They dont want to stay alone. They are alone because maybe they dont have company with similar interests or there is too much stupidity around them so they isolate themselves. Actually no one wants to stay alone, life would be miserable that way and trust me i have experienced it myself

I think there was a study that came out recently about this, confirming the idea to some degree. Thinking requires solitude. You can’t think very carefully while you’re drinking with your pals. And if thinking is important to you, you’d want to do it a little more than most. That’s my guess.

I am sure there are some relevant surveys on this issue, complete with desirably pertinent data. I have not read them, but for a purely guesstimatory jaunt through this field of inquiry, let me speculate that yes, there is a higher prevalence of isolation or lack of connection for the highly intelligent. I cannot back that up and it is entirely possible I am wrong.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Laurie Schlangen Traub and Juan Antonio

response.answer_text: First of, labelling someone as smart is very subjective (and vague). For some, being smart may mean getting their work done, swiftly, without much effort. For others, it can mean doing work in a different unconventional way that is innovative. Some people may attach the word smart with being wise, and so on. However, if I'm able to understand what you meant by smart here is - Someone who is wiser than average to handle problems and innovate solutions that are often unconventional for commoners. If that is so, I'd say a No to your question (Not in absolutism but a rather generalisation). Yes, such people may sometimes feel like not engaging with others who can't entertain their curiosity but it is not to say that they love loneliness. They're too as you and me. Like, you may not like to spend time with my type of friends or I might not like your taste of companionship. Similarly everyone has their own cirlce that they'd like to be in. In a nutshell, I'd say- Everyone has their own set of choices. But everyone likes companionship. [Hafsa Samreen, thankyou for asking]>

Think of it this way… If you don't want to be stabbed, would you be around stabaholics !? If intelligent people can/want to be dumb, they would have already been traveling down the dumb path. Thus, no one would question their isolation.

For dumbasses, the more you act “intelligently”, the less you’ll be accepted. For “intelligent” ones, the more you act like a dumbass, the less you’ll be accepted. Where you belong within this spectrum is how you’ll isolate/accept another. Remember, intelligent people never feel isolated and never isolate people.

Being smart has nothing to do with being alone. What matters is whether you spend your attention on noticing and expressing differences with people, or joining in on common ideas and attributes.  Whatever you focus on is what gets manifested for you. It's a life long process of noticing and being responsible for how you react to other people.

hi Desiderata Max Ehrmann, writer and lawyer (1872-1945) Go placidly amid the noise and the haste and rememeber what peace there may be in silence. Smart people come in all kinds and colors. There are smart introverts, smart extroverts, smart people who want relationships and smart people who don't. If you have a lot going on in your head, often you will need some time on your own to just consider your thoughts in peace. On the other hand, some people's smartness and creativity shows the best when they are in a group, and, for example, act as a leader. So, as with all generalizing questions - it depends.
